Rainbow Six is back with a new title and it's only multiplayer, but will you want to play it ?  Rainbow Six Siege the new game in the Rainbow Six series. This game rose up from the ashes of what once was Rainbow Six Patriots.   The game is set in current times where the fight against terrorism is full blown out. Terrorist are conducting massive attacks around the world and you play as either the terrorists or the rainbow unit which consists of worldwide response units.   As stated before the game has no story whatsoever. The only thing you can do solo is a situation mode which teaches you the basics of the game and the incredibly fun Terrorist Hunt mode. The game has one story mission which is online only which tasks you to go to a US college and defuse a toxic bomb, the mission is notable because it obscures your vision with toxic gas and you need to work as a team to defuse the bombs, cause the mission is really difficult.  The AI for solo mode is not stupid so you won't be able to Rambo the entire map. You will have to be smart with your actions since the AI is pretty smart. They change up they're routes and will try to flank you and rush you any chance they get, they're aim is pretty good as well.   Now for the reason you might want to buy the game, THE PVP.   Trust me when I say this, the game is no joke. This game is incredibly difficult and doesn't hold your hand. You will need to work as a team if you want to win. A well placed shot will take you out and a well planned attack might earn you a sweet victory.  The game suits many play styles, from a support who helps out teammates in the field, to a pyromaniac who likes to blow up everything in sight. You will definitely find an operator that suits you the best.  Even though there's not many maps, each map is very dynamic. It's big enough for you to defend, but no matter what remember, you are never safe. You can destroy almost every wall, ceiling or floor so you never feel safe no matter how good your defenses are.   The game has one major flaw and that's the horrible servers. The servers are way too unpredictable. At one moment they work fine, the other they won't give you any money or won't even load you to the game. Ubisoft stated that they are working on fixing this issue so I trust them to get it sorted out.  The game is optimised incredibly well. It runs at 60 fps maxed out. If you have a high end PC you will have no trouble running this game.  In the end do I recommend the game ? Yes I do. I do suggest at the very least waiting for the server issue to be fixed and you have one of the best squad based games ever made. Get a few friends for the ride and you have one incredible game on your hands.  Final Rating: 9/10 - A must own (after servers are fixed)  If you liked this review please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you disliked post in the comments on what you disliked about the review. UPDATED REVIEW (Andjusted Review for BLACK ICE UPDATE!)  I've put many more hours and was finally able to play ranked matches since my last uninformed review. So here's my stance on the game right now: ♥♥♥♥ing Fantastic, for the most part anyway.  This game has everything it needs to grow a reliable and consistent playerbase. Rainbow Six Siege's asymmetric style of gameplay is unique, and it seems very fresh. This arena shooter pits two teams of 5 operators against each other in intense extremely close quarters combat. The environment could be either your biggest ally or your worst enemy, depending on which team you're on or how your team's been handling a situation. While I think this game is great I cannot argue that it has some issues. Here are simple pros and cons to wet your appetite for destruction.  PROS:  - Fantastic destruction based gameplay forces you to think and adapt to any situation.  - Has serious competitive potential. Ranked mode is good, but obviously the people playing for keeps aren't so nice. Ever.  - SO MANY OPERATORS!  CONS:  - Microphone communication is a must. Text chat is limited to less than 6 words, making communication difficult for those who are either afraid to talk to people, or don't have a microphone. Sometimes, people don't even talk. At all. This makes the game unwinnable a lot. (EDIT: UBISOFT HAS EXPANDED THE AMOUNT OF LETTERS IN TEXT CHAT SIGNIFICANTLY, DISREGARD)  - The community is very hit or miss at best. One can play 10-12 games and only 2 out of those 10-12 would be good, fair, non ♥♥♥♥♥y teammates who take responsibility for their shortcomings instead of blaming the rest of the team. Blaming the rest of the team is only okay if the rest of the team is actually to blame, which is often not the case.  - Matchmaking seems to enjoy hooking people up globally. Which means that damn language barrier strikes again.  - Terrorist hunt. My darling Terrorist hunt what have they done to you... Classic Terrorist Hunt mode is a rarity at best when Ubisoft decided it would be a good idea to just shoehorn in other game modes. And they're terrible.  Overall, Rainbow Six Siege is a great team based game if you have a mic, patience, and good sportsmanship. So grab a corner, make yourself comfortable, and pray to god the enemy team doesn't have Thermite.  7/10  P.S.: The reviews angelizing the community are incredibly situational and subjective. Those reviewers got lucky and got matched up with great players. I never do. Don't buy the game based on the community because you will be thoroughly disappointed.  BLACK ICE UPDATE: Oh Ubisoft. You make me so happy but also so, so mad. Black Ice is the first official content update of R6 Siege and it looks promising. It adds a new map and two new operators. It was released on Feb 2nd, but I can't access the content until the 8th... what the hell Ubisoft. They are pushing this season pass HARD.  I considered lowering the score and giving the game a thumbs down but hell. Every AAA company pushes their season passes so who cares. I can wait a tad longer. I am glad that I get access to the balance update at least. And boy what a hefty balance update it is. Also I found it hilarious to see that Ubisoft still has a sense of humor.   Thatcher finally got his shotgun. Thanks, Ubi.

This feels like the evolution of Counter Strike. I've got that same addiction feeling I remember from the original CS as a HL mod. Remember the 747 CS map? Well Siege has a plane, and it's everything I wanted the CS 747 mission to be.  My personal strategies evolve as I play, when I die sometimes it means my strategy needs adjusting, or there is a vulnurability I need to be aware of. Other times I rage quit. But when it all comes together... it's very satisfying.  At first I was annoyed that you had to unlock operators, but I realized that each one has a bit of a learning curve, so by the time you play with one for a while you can unlock the next one, not really a big deal. It's also good to know if you have a more expensive operator on your team, it's probably someone experienced, so you might want to stick with them.  I guess my only complaint is the 'peekers advantage'. If you peek around a corner you can shoot someone before they even see you (by a fraction of a second). This actualy gives an advantage to players with a high ping. I get that this is a technical limitation, but it does force me to defend as a roamer instead of camping in the objective room (which would be fun).

If you enjoy Rainbow Six series then I am sure you might enjoy this one, but only just I would say.  The game has changed in many ways and I do have a problem with the game, which I will get into in a moment.  Graphics: The graphics are obviously updated since any other Rainbow Six game, which is good but they are not as amazing as we would like them too be. They are pretty decent still to say, but that's about it. I do not expect much because of this, the graphics are just a modern game at that....   Audio: The audio I find to be louder than what it is, when shooting a gun it sounds like a rocket is going BANG in your ear, no matter inside or out and feels rushed together just to make it sound like something is happening, rather than the game actually sounding like a firing weapon in a small space, outside or in a large room... Slightly annoying or confusing at times.  Controls: The controlling of the character is very easy to get ahold and kinda more arcade style movement than originally thought... It feels more of a slowed down Counter Strike movement, not quiet the arcade CS controls but a slower version to make it seem more realistic. The buttons and stuff are easy to do and get used too..  Game: The game itself right now on release as I write this article (I will update after the first year so people better understand how it has moved along) is that it has 3 modes, multiplayer/ Terrorist Hunt and kinda like scenario situations, where there are about 8 missions, you must gain 3 stars in each mission to basically pass, each mission is a different thing BUT it feels like a tutorial for each class and how to use and play as them, mixed in the 3 star system from the old Modern Warfare 2 coop system, where you had to defend for X amount of time for 3 stars etc (If you played MW2 coop, you will know about the star coop system)  Terrorist Hunt has 3 difficulties, Normal, Hard and Realistic... Basically realistic is hacking bots, this I seen being stupid... I watched my death cam, a bot instantly stepped into a room looking right and did not see my team, then INSTANTLY span directly to the left almost a 360 degree spin pin point accuracy, fired and killed 2 people... Stupid. Basically you hunt the map to kill how ever many bots... That is terrorist hunt.  The games you play as multiplayer are fast at times but thankfully the loading is almost instant, so you are in and out without any massive waiting so games are always on the go, which is a plus when you have a stupid team and the other being pro's.  My annoyance and many feel the same: The game has a kinda cash system, where you give Ubisoft MORE money than they already recieve, in return you buy ingame cash and use that cash to pay for items in the game like more operators, gun attachments, skins and so on... The game itself is built around this and you earn a small amount of renown ingame gold stuff to actually buy stuff, this I noticed to be a lot of playing (farming) to get the gold you need to upgrade, when you could just spend more money on a game with limited gameplay and get the stuff you want straight away. You can now buy items with renown but some items are locked behind the real money system like boosts or packs etc. Also items are very very very expensive with renown!  The game was delayed once or twice, I cannot remember.. It might have been more but I played the closed beta, open beta and so on and between those times I cannot see why the game took so long to make. It barely has any content to keep someone playing for hours and barely has anything to warrant the huge price tag they want for it... Ubisoft for you I guess.   The game on release has barely any content I found... The maps, modes and whatever else is barely anything for what I would expect a bran new game to have.   Would I recommend the game? Yes and no, sadly Steam does not allow this option for limo.  Yes, if you enjoy the Rainbow Six Series and like team work, small maps, quick games, weird shooting to rescue a hostage, or defuse a bomb and secure the area (Basically a bomb but no defuser) (Seriously that's the only three options.....)  No, if you do not like barely any content, cash ingame microtransactions system and medicore experience.  Ubisoft needs to do some major work on this game and release a hell load of free stuff and stuff for gold edition to make this game something that it was supposed to be, the game had so much hype on what it was going to be but utterly it falls short by quiet a bit which is sad. I wanted to love thie game but ended up more frustrated than anything else. Ubisoft also seems to be turning into a company which throws anything together with a slapping big price tag and thinks it's justified with their name, it's worth it all and it's amazing...

I've always been a huge fan of the Rainbow Six games and put hundreds of hours into Vegas 2 before Siege came out, and I love this game as well. It's addictive and dynamic enough that you don't get bored of playing the same maps and game modes over and over; every round will play out a little differently.   With that being said, I have a couple points of criticism:  1. The matchmaking system sucks. I wish it didn't, but it's my main problem with the game. One of the problems is it will begin searching for an opposing team prematurely before filling up your team roster, perhaps in anticipation that it can find the remaining players while it matches you up with the opposition, but more often than not it gets stuck in a loop of finding teammates to looking for an enemy team, and the only way out of it is to quit matchmaking and reenter the queue. Other times, it will continue searching for teammates after the roster is already full instead of for an enemy team, or it will continuously loop between searching for teammates and finding an enemy team for no apparent reason even after the roster is full.   As a result of these problems, you either spend over five minutes queuing or have to quit and rejoin the queue. It may seem like a trivial amount of time but it adds up quickly and is genuinely irritating. Aside from that, there doesn't seem to be much rhyme or reason to who you get matched up with or against, especially in ranked. I've seen level 40s get paired with people over level 100, and bronze tier players get pitted against a team of silver tier players. Frankly it results in the same sort of 'ELO hell' that players complain about in games like League of Legends, and needs fixed, especially for the ranked system.   2. There's a major lack of player statistics, both for yourself and other players. For a game that's basically multiplayer only, I'd expect it to maintain some record of things (comparable to say, Battlefield) like K/D ratio, win/loss ratio, score per minute, most played classes and weapons, accuracy %, etc. I've only been able to find very rudimentary stats for ranked games only, which doens't really help a player to reflect on their performance. In searching for people to play with in multiplayer, it would help to have these stats available to be able to better predict their performance.  3. Network lag. Too many times have I gotten killed from around a corner by someone that wasn't there when I was peaking. The kill cam shows a much different view than I had. Accomodating for potential lag when peaking is basically part of the game at this point, and I have a pretty stellar internet connection it's pretty annoying. Another fix needed here.  With all that being said, and I may come across as rather harsh, I still love this game to death and play every day. I hope that these problems are addressed in future updates.

This game is a tactical first person shooter which involves two sides, the attackers and defenders. The attackers are required to secure or capture an objective such as a hostage or biohazard/bomb while the defence team set up barricades and traps to stop them. There are also 20 operators to play from, each with unique abilities and weapons that can be used in many different situations as well as there being dedicated attack and defend operators.   There are also three gamemodes and they each use this playstyle. There is competitive multiplayer, terrorist hunt (player vs AI) and situations (singleplayer). The singleplayer is used to put you into many different scenarios involving hostages, biohazards and bombs to use different operators and abilities to win. You can earn stars for completing specific goals in each situations which also earn you renown points, the in-game currency used to purchase operators. Terrorist Hunt involves a team of players fighting their way to the objective through AI bots, the cooperative component.   The positives: - Really fun. - Very good looking graphics. - Creative use of tools, gadgets and weaponry they are fun to use and play.  - A different variety of operators to choose from. - Additional operators and maps added through free DLC.  The negatives: - Other players can be offputting and abusive (teamkilling, swearing etc.) - The banning system could use a lot of work (which is getting better gradually) - Players decide to report you for no reason just to be annoying.  I have personally really enjoyed playing this and have had so much fun with a different experience everytime I play being able to choose from many different operators adding plenty of variety. The visuals are very pleasing to look at and the tactical gameplay is amazing. I recommend this game if you can put up with annoying players as apart from that it is a really good experience. This game will keep you playing for hours.

I feel that I've played this game enough to have a strong opinion of it. I've never played one second of any previous Rainbow Six game before and I am sad because I now know what I was missing. Competetive FPS's I played in the past were Call of Duty and Battlefield which are different to each other and especially different to Rainbow Six Siege. Rainbow Six Siege really rewards strategy, patience and accuracy in spades. You can't just go in guns blazin' and expect to succeed. This is especially true in multiplayer. You have to scope out your enemy and plan on how to infiltrate or defend the building. There are 26 operators (13 on offense and 13 on defense) all with different abilities and uses. It's important to know the strengths and weaknesses of the operator you're currently using and to use their specialties to their maximum effectiveness. What I love about this game is that if you die once, you're out until the next round. One minor screw up or victory has a bigger impact on the outcome of the match. Siege has Co-op as well and can definitely be very fun either with randoms, friends or lone wolf, but the real draw and addictivness of the game comes from out smarting and out maneuvering the enemy team in multiplayer. In CoD and BF, it's definitely satisfying to get a kill, but a kill in Siege is so much more rewarding and special. There are no kill streaks and crazy battles. There are just 2 small groups of tactical soldiers that have small skirmishes in a building, and it's exhilerating and suspenseful as hell.

This game has so many pros and only one to two cons. There is so much diversity in this game every person can find an operator that suits their play style the best. I have never played a round in almost 500 hours that played the same as another. The only con in this game is the servers, which are not as bad as everyone says. The only other con is the lighting for looking outside as a defender, sometimes it is insanely bright and other times it is fine.  Firstly, every single operator has a different playstyle. Thermite, Hibana, ash, and sledge are all about destroying walls, floors, and ceilings. However, they do it in their own special way; Thermite makes a giant hole in reinforced walls/floors that your team can go through, Ash can blow open wooden barricade, placable shields, floor panels from a distance with her Breaching Rounds (And they aren't blocked by mute), Hibana is like a mix between Ash and Thermite she can open small holes in reinforced that you can look through but not walk through (You can make the holes on the bottom and crawl though), and Sledge uses his sledge hammer to breach holes in wooden wall, floors, and castle +mute barricades. These are just a few operators that the attackers can have; they can have Thatcher who can destroy electronics with his EMP grenade, Fuze who can fill a room with grenade with his cluster charge, IQ who can find find electronics through walls, and Many more fun and unique characters to play.  Defenders also have unique characters who all have different gadgets and play styles. Rook is the ultimate defended operator, his gadget is armor plating that him and his teammates can pick up (Armor makes it harder for attackers to kill you and your team). Jager can place down an ADS (also know as Active Defense System) which shoots down grenades the come into its range. Mute can jam wireless electronics (Which include breaching charges, thermite charge, and drones). Bandit is similar to mute, however, Bandit destroys the electronics (However the batteries must be placed on metal objects like reinforced walls, deployable shields, and barbed wire)   Secondly, Even after 500 hours of play since release of this game I have never played a similar round. Even with only about a dozen maps and 3 games modes no round is ever the same. Every time you go into a new round there is always a trick someone pulls that wins the round. Even when you play against the same people who are playing the same characters while your team is playing the same characters on the same game mode and same objective room as the last time the round will be different from the last one. If the attackers lost they will definitely try and new attacking strategy, however the defenders will know this and change how the defend the area and where they are hiding within the map. There are always new holes you kind find to shoot thought, I have played these maps over and over so many times but I still find new holes I can make to get easy kills.   Lastly, and sadly the only con in this game I can find are the servers. The servers and hitreg in this game can be horrible at times. They can be absolutely game breaking. I have lost countless rounds because the servers do not detect the headshot I got on an enemy, however, I won many rounds for the same reason (Even though I won the round I still felt like I was cheated out of a fair game).   The only other con is the lighting. The lighting is much better than the servers, but they are still hit and miss at times. Sometimes the lights look like the sun is 2 feet from the window and other times it works like intended. (One map is especially bad, Yacht, as it is covered in snow and the lighting is insanely bad. At times you are inside looking up a set of stairs that are inside and still be blinded by light)   Even in this review I wasn't able to talk about the amount of love put into this game by Ubisoft. an entire year of update and 4 DLC patchs this game is still my favorite to play. I know everyone just read that Ubisoft and 4 DLCs and groaned a little on the inside, but these DLCs are completely free to everyone (But you can still buy a pass that lets you play the new character a week before everyone else). The developers constantly give love to this game with constant updates that improve the game every time.   I can honestly say this is my favorite game I have ever played. Even after a year of playing I never get tried of booting up to play a few rounds. I can honestly say I have never been happier than when a new DLC is announced and when year 2 of DLC was announced I was insanely happy that this game survived has survived this long (And is growing). Even after a year after is release I would still recommend this game to anyone who wants a tactical teambased FPS.  TL;DR Even after a year game is going strong with new updates every couple months with FREE DLC every 3 moths. Every character is unique and fun to play. If you are planning on purchasing the game, here are a few things you should know:  This game is almost exclusively multiplayer, though it does contain 10 Single Player scenarios called 'Situations'. You will have to register on UPlay, and everything ingame will be linked to your UPlay account, NOT your Steam account. You are simply purchasing the product via Steam. The game has a slight difficulty curve, and several of the tactics and strategies involved, you are expected to learn on your own, since there is very little Single Player content, and you jump straight into Multiplayer.  The game contains in-game microtransactions, for unlocking operators, weapon attachments and in game cosmetics. These can be purchased either using premium R6S credits or Renown earned in-game. The pricing is such that you should be done unlocking your operators and attachments very fast, and the only real grind is for getting cosmetics and DLC operators. The game has a 'Season Pass' system. You can purchase Year 2 Pass currently, and a Legacy operator bundle for getting the season 1 content. What a Season Pass does is allow you to unlock all DLC operators for free and use them 1 week prior to others being able to. Even if you don't own a Season Pass you can still get these operators, you just have to grind enough Renown points for them (25k for each operator ~ 15-20 hours). So in that sense, once you purchase the base game, you are able to access all the content for no extra charge, which is great because Ubisoft is still adding new content and supporting the game. The season pass also comes with added benefits such as Renown Booster, extra credits, Store Discounts, exclusive skins etc and in my opinion is worth it if you have the money.    The game does contain some bugs related to hit registration and this annoying problem that happens when you look out of a window and you can't see anything. But these are being worked on, and there have been improvements in the recent patch, and since there has been another year of content promised, we can expect these to be fixed. The matchmaking system is also a pain in the ♥♥♥ for Lower Level players since you almost always get teamed up and against higher level people, which is frustrating for both parties. However, this gets better once you learn the game and get at a higher level. There is also a Ranked match system where you get various tiers based on your skill level.    Overall, at this price I believe this game has offered my my money's worth. If the concept of such an FPS interests you, and you are tired of the same repetitive type 'Run and gun' gameplay of CoD, I'd say give this a shot.

Competitive games are a big business these days with thousands of people watching their favorite pro teams or players battling it out in their favorite games. Ubisoft never really had a game to attempt to compete with the competitive game scene. So now they made their first attempt by bringing Rainbow Six Siege. Here are my thoughts about Rainbow Six Siege.   The Story   This is gonna be a short one. There basically isn't any story mode in Rainbow Six Siege. You do see an intro about some unknown terrorist organization planning attacks around the world. But it is unclear why they even planning these attacks.  In the game itself there is no singleplayer story mode. Ubisoft stated that the focus on Rainbow Six Siege was mainly on compelling cooperative and multiplayer experience. It does however has singleplayer terrorist hunt and training missions. Which let you get familiar with the different operators to choose from. So what more does Rainbow Six Siege has to offer?   Terrorist Hunt   In terrorist hunt you play different missions on either normal, hard or realistic difficulty with either friends or random people versus a.i. controlled enemies. These missions are almost the same as the multiplayer. But the difference is that in terrorist hunt more enemies will swarm around since they are a.i. controlled enemies. But don't let their appearance fool you. These a.i. enemies will literally break down doors and windows to hunt you down. Or even blow themselves up while taking you with them.   Multiplayer   The multiplayer in Rainbow Six Siege is the cream of the crop. In the multiplayer you have the attacking and defending side. The attacking side has to either rescue a hostage, defuse a bomb or capture a bomb side while the defending side had to prevent it.  At the start of a match you pick one of the twenty-six operators depending on if you are attacking or defending. All these operators needs to be unlocked by earning renown that you earn by playing the game.  When everyone has picked their operator the 45 seconds preparation timer is starting. Within this time the attacking team needs to locate the objective and find the defending team.  The defending team however has to prepare for the coming attack. They can do this by reinforce walls so they can't be breached, setting up traps and get in position for the attack.  After the preparation timer it time to start the siege. At this point the round has 4 minutes left for the both teams to eliminate or secure the objective.  But what makes the gameplay so great is that every around feels like a problem solving game. Most of the times you really need to plan how you want to breach in a building. One big part of the problem solving is what operator did you picked to breach.  For instance on the attacking side the operator Termite is has two Exothermic charges which lets you breach reinforced walls. Termite is only one of the two operators able to blow up reinforced walls. Which makes him useful to create a new path.  But if we look at the defending side there is the operator Mute that can place signal disrupter's. And if placed at reinforced wall Termite cant use his Exothermic charge anymore until the signal disrupter is destroyed.  Its basically feels like a rock, paper and scissors game.  This is what I like the most about Rainbow Six Siege. It's satisfying to play a game with slow paced teamwork. And the feeling that very round feels different and unpredictable makes it great.   Season Pass   Yes, almost every game these days has a season pass and Rainbow Six Siege isn't any different. But it is important to mention that the season pass of Rainbow Six Siege is different as most other games.  Because you don't need the season pass to play new maps or new released operators. They are being released for free for everyone to play.  The thing season pass owners get is some exclusive skins, instantly unlock new operators and get a week early play time with these new operators.  But all the new maps are free for everyone to enjoy. And the new operators can be unlocked by renown by everyone with renown.  Final Verdict  Are you looking for a bit slower paced shooter and thinking a bit more strategic before rushing in a building with enemies. Than you should definitely try this game out.   I give Rainbow Six Siege a 8,5 out of 10

Check out what happened in one of the last rounds I played and decide if you wanna go through an experience like this:  We attack. Sledge hammers the front door down while Blitz and Fuze rappel up the windows. The bomb is on the first floor. We know it cause our drones had succesfully located it before.  I chose Thermite and I'm glad I did. I brake through a window and see reinforced walls all over the place. I smile and set my special charge. One wall is down and I can hear them running around and repositioning. I let my team know.  I quickly place another Thermite's special on the opposite wall (just to stir even more panic) and I hide. The wall melts and explodes. I throw my grenades which destroy 3 of their devices. Unfortunately, no kills for me.  I hear Fuze's special grenades: great effect on target and 2 enemies down. As Blitz makes his way in hiding behind his shield, Montagne (I didn't even remember he was there) walks slowly with his shield from head to toe. I hitch a ride and we advance as one.  The enemy manages to kill Fuze. Blitz also falls, but not before blinding one of them and making him an easy pray for Montagne, who promptly hides behind his fortress again as soon as he's done getting revenge for our team.  Sledge finishes the job skillfully: he sets the defuser after killing an enemy. Now there's one tango left, so we just wait. He must do something or he will let his teammates down for not even trying. He comes, I try to kill him and I die. Montagne doesn't.  We win. We cheer and praise eachother. I add some of the players to my buddy list.  As for me, I had no kills or assists, but the 'doors' I opened (and only I could open them) paved our way to success. And that's how we roll in Rainbow 6 Siege.

Not recommending purchasing Season Pass, unless you're a die-hard Rainbow Six fan.   I'll make this quick by making a statement and why:   PROS:  -Graphics is great. Great if you want a good slap of realism and then realise you forgot to reload or ran out of explosives. -Immersive. Hear footsteps, shoot towards it. Hear Darth Vader coming, shoot it in the head. Hear 2 Darth Vaders coming, good luck. -Requires a bit of thinking.   Unlike Call of Duty.   -Great Community. Can't opt to carry on with the match without 5th player. -Lack of a 'Story' mode. My opinion though. -Could use a bit more customization on weapons or armour. My opinion though.   Overall: 7/10

These are my first impressions: i just got this game. rainbow six siege, and intresting title, and imo, a fun one. people talk about bugs and hackers but i have yet to see either in my time of play so my opinion may be biased in that way, maybe i just got lucky. So basically this is a game where the premise is 2 teams, OPfor and BLUfor in which one team defends and objective while the other attempts to break into the compound/building using tools, as the defenders have a preparation time to use their tools to make a strong defense. the tools are class system based meaning the hero you choose will have certain situational uses, im sure there are some classes that are underpowered, i just havnt been able to use them all yet as i only have 4 so far, and out of those 4 the tools are pretty neat. weapon customization is pretty regular, they use a system where you buy weapon attatchments (no need to buy guns because weapon options are pre seleteced for your class, the 'currency' you use to buy the stuff with is easy because you get a ♥♥♥♥ load of it after you finish a game (especially if you did good) the game is also based around a leveloution type system as to MOST (not all) walls/interiors are able to be broken, as much as going down to a SINGLE BULLET can make a tiny hole the size of a bullet, i've personally never seen that attention to detail to leveloution in my experience before. the gunplay is honestly pretty generic but something about the leveloution and gunplay goes together like peanut butter and jelly and it feels right even with the generic gunplay, because the world (or building heh) you're in feels dynamic as most of it can be broken with guns/explosives i also personally like the gunsounds in this game, they sound meaty when they shoot but not trying to be hyper realistic in any way, feels just right. i honestly cant say much about map design yet because i have not been familiar with the maps enough yet. i also feel like this game is pretty easy to take on if your familiar with FPS games, as i took it on pretty quick and began rackin in kills. all in all so far its pretty fun

Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is the upcoming installment of the acclaimed first-person shooter franchise developed by the renowned Ubisoft Montreal studio.   Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege invites players to master the art of destruction. Intense close quarters confrontations, high lethality, tactics, team play, and explosive action are at the center of the experience. The gameplay sets a new bar for intense firefights and expert strategy in the rich legacy of past Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six games. Key Features THE SIEGE GAMEPLAY  For the first time in Rainbow Six, players will engage in sieges, a brand-new style of assault. Enemies now have the means to transform their environments into strongholds: they can trap, fortify, and create defensive systems to prevent breach by Rainbow teams.   To face this challenge, players have a level of freedom unrivaled by any previous Rainbow Six game. Combining tactical maps, observation drones, and a new rappel system, Rainbow teams have more options than ever before to plan, attack, and diffuse these situations.    COUNTER TERRORIST UNITS  Counter terrorist operatives are trained to handle extreme situations, such as hostage rescue, with surgical precision. As “short range” specialists, their training is concentrated on indoor environments. Operating in tight formations, they are experts of close quarter combat, demolition, and coordinated assaults. Rainbow Six Siege will include operators coming from five of the most worldwide renowned CTU: the British SAS, the American SWAT, the French GIGN, the German GSG9 and the Russian SPETSNAZ.   These Operators are specialists with their own expertise within Siege operations. Each has their own unique personality & specialty. Some are focused on assault where as others are defense-oriented. They can be combined within the same team to create new team strategies.    PROCEDURAL DESTRUCTION  Destruction is at the heart of the siege gameplay. Players now have the unprecedented ability to destroy environments. Walls can be shattered, opening new lines of fire, and ceiling and floors can be breached, creating new access points. Everything in the environment reacts realistically, dynamically, and uniquely based on the size and caliber of bullets you are using or the amount of explosives you have set. In Rainbow Six Siege, destruction is meaningful and mastering it is often the key to victory.

This game is intense! Even though it's from Ubi *cough* *WatchDogs* soft, the game is actually good, and this is coming from a player that has played ALOT of Battlefield, Call of duty, Arma, and Counter Strike. The game is very competitive, the shooting feels like Battlefield, but the feeling that the enemy could come from anywhere at anytime(destructible environments) is surprisingly very DayZ like. the competitive atmosphere is similar to CSGO, but it's better than CS in many aspects.   There is a greater emphasis in teamwork, in CS you can pretty much carry yourself and your friends to the higher ranks if you have good aim alone. Here in R6, aim will not save you. your teammates will, literally(through revives). But unliterally, there are classes to unlock and to choose from that can compliment/counter other classes. For example, in the defenders, you can place electricity to metal surfaces to keep away intruders which can be countered by another class(disabler of electronics) on the attacker side, kill that disabler class early in the game and they can't disable the electricity and in-turn destroy that wall, and they have less options to breach in. Grenades can be countered by an anti-grenade system, which can be disabled as well. Different classes have different abilities which can help your team win the round. You can select your loadout, and stuff your weapons with attachments depending on your preference.  There are a lot of maps, ranging from small to large, and every round, the position of the defending side is randomized(in casual, but in ranked your team can vote to choose one of many sites), and the attacking team have to find them, usually by the use of small drones. This is very different to CSGO where sites are fixed and chokepoints are the same over and over and over again. Again, we have destructible environments so pretty much the enemy can come from any side, especially if the place you are defending has a ceiling, basement and windows.  aside from the usual 5v5 casual/ranked PvP matches, there are single player missions to complete and the Terrorist Hunt COOP/lonewolf vs AI game mode like in Rainbow Six Vegas.  The only downside I can think of is the hackers, I haven't met one myself(mainly due to mostly playing casual atm) but I've heard the game is full of them. I've heard the game is buggy as well, but I haven't found any huge game breaking bugs atm.  9.5/10

its tactical, slow but full of tension. playing 5vs.5 is more thrilling than playing against 20+ in COD or BF. teamwork is essential and thats what everyone wants. one of the reasons i have stopped playing COD and BF because teamwork can not be found there. it is a breath of fresh air with many classes and customization to unlock. hubs are fairly sized and the objectives are never at the same place. it is like SWAT 3 and 4, only having players playing as the bad guys. each round you either play as the attacker or the defender. playing classes like: POLIZEI (german for police), SAS, FBI/SWAT and few more known assault teams from around the world. each class has 2 attacker and defender type. which can be all unlocked when having enough XP.  attacker: beginning of each round, you control little droids with a camera to locate enemies and your target. not always successful if the enemy team has set jamers or shoots your droid preventing you from finding the objective. then you raid the place by using your equipment of the class you have chosen like breaching through a wall with explosives, sending droids, grenade launcher and more.  defender: fortify an area by setting up laser mines, barbwire, blocking walls/doors/windows with boards and even electrify them to prevent the enemy from approaching them. the standard boarding, for every class (except one), for windows and doors are usually out of wood and obviously not possible to electrify them. then its pretty much holding out until everyone of the enemy team is defeated or your self. it my be camping but still not as easy as you may think at first.  there is a 'situation' mode which is a training session to introduce you to most characters and what modes you will face in the MP. worth playing since they arent A game for the ages, Rainbow 6 siege really redefines what a cooperative FPS can be. Challenging and extremely rewarding, Siege is a beautiful masterpiece. The community is amazing, people actually work together and communicate. At the end of a game there is a true sense of comradery with your fellow team members. You all went through that together whether you won or not.   The gameplay mechanics are also top notch, you will always be learning new ways to use the destructible environment to your advantage and likewise having it used against you. A lot of thought has gone into the operator system, there are no glaring imbalances and it makes for some interesting plays. For example reading these reviews you will see Fuze killing hostages a lot. A lot of the time if you pick Fuze on a hostage map people will wonder what you are up to, yet if you place it safely away from the hostage the other team will never see it coming. This is just one example of the constantly adapting strategies throughout this game. It’s a game where thinking is equally as important as quick reflexes. And the first time you manage to outsmart the entire team and get that ACE… my goodness, you will never forget it.   Now I personally have had no issues with the servers or cheaters, I know people do though. However Ubisoft are very active in developing this game, and have a constant presence on reddit and their forums letting people know the status on various bugs they are working on. They do seem determined to make this a success. As they should be, it is an amazing game and it’s a shame it started out so bumpy. I am every bit confident that they will sort out the issues some people are facing in due time. Keep in mind though that it’s generally the people that are having issues that we hear the stories about, not the majority that are having a great time.   I'd fully recommend the game, especially on a steam sale, you have nothing to lose.  10/10  UPDATE 25th Nov 2016  Since writing my previous review there have been a large number of changes to the game. Most noticiable is the introduction of battleye anticheat which has all but removed cheaters from the game. It took its time for the suspicions of players to die down but now that crazy death out of no where is more amazing than tilting. The recent DLCs have shaken up the meta in great new ways, people have to adjust their stratagies and play styles to compensate, always a good thing.   People complain the game is now more fast paced, no more camping in rooms waiting for the attackers to arrive. This is however not so much a symptom of the new DLC characters but more the playerbase has matured and the meta has naturally changed. If all the DLC characters were removed, people wouldn't all suddenly return to camping one room, its just not a good stratagy.   This is a great game, and only gets beter with every new update and every new player.

If Squad is what America's Army 3 should have been, this is what America's Army Proving Grounds should have been.  Ever read Rainbow Six? Yes? Imagine  a real version of the SWAT computer training program.  If not, this is going to be a bit hard to explain. Unlike the other Rainbow games, which are all about using tactics and communication to coordinate your attacks, this game allows you to do that for the defending side as well and also adds another factor into the max: destruction. Whether it be causing or preventing it, each operator has gadgets that help them cause it. Whether it be as simple as a Primacord charge or a flashbang to a wall penetrating grenade launcher or a drone able to take out gadgets with a taser, all operators have them. Also being able to shoot through walls. The gunplay requires you to think smart, too. Most guns can kill in three hits, and the ones that can't are either shock drones or have a terrifying rate of fire. But what matters the most is this:  all headshots kill.  No DBNO state, no heavy damage, death. This requires players to think instead of just running and gunning. Contrary to series' like Call of Duty, where shooting someone with a Magnum round in point blank range just leaves them with a bloody monitor.  So, it's like the typical close range objective shooter but actually fun. Get it if you want. I won't force you.  (don't look at my hours, I played the beta too)

I'm not going to decide to say yes or no to a recommendation until I finish this review:  First of all, the pros:  >This game is probably the most realistic first person shooter on the market at the moment. There are so many options and things you can do on this game that makes it so much different than any other shooter, which is probably why I like it. For me, I'm not generally into these kinds of games, but if you want a first person strategy game that actually requires you work together to succeed, this game is for you. It's not a silly run-n-gun like COD. Which brings me to another good point: This community is actually pretty awesome. Most of the players are 18+ and relatively mature for what it is. Hardly ever will you ever encounter an annoying 14 year old on a mic being obnoxious. That's happened to me twice in the 100+ hours of gameplay that I have, and each time they've been kicked. Nobody wants to deal with that, so they don't.   Cons:  >The ONLY complaint I have about this game is how poorly the servers are ran. If you're not constantly DC'ing during or before the match starts, you have to worry after every single game whether or not it's going to 'Synchronize your data' right before you get your XP and 'Reknown' (currency). If that happens, you just wasted 10-20 minutes on that match. I wouldn't complain if this was an uncommon ocurrence, but it's not. I've had it happen four matches in a row. After the 100+ hours of gameplay, I've only reached level 29/(I don't believe there is a max level). I guarantee I'd be 35+ if it didn't constantly 'synchronize my data.'    I guess I'm going to say that I recommend this game, seeing as the only cons are something on Ubisoft's end and not the actual gameplay. If you don't have patience, I probably wouldn't, seeing as you're probably going to want to chuck your PC out of a window after DC'ing five games in a row. The game is great in itself, but like I said, be weary of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ servers. Uber Soft needs to step it up.

Been playing the game since beta. Its had ups and downs. It's good to see the game thrive in a world dominated by CoD and Battlefield. Probably my favourite shooter of the year.  Sure it has its issues: bullets not registering hits, exploits, crashes, hackers, Fuze on hostage but the game also has its moments.   At its core it is a solid shooter with the potential to become an esport if most of the major bugs and exploits are patched, the hacking has become noticeably less with the introduction of Battleye (probably the only game where Battleye actually works) and has an interesting array of operators who work in their own unique way but work with each other also. Not to mention an active and enthusiastic player base on the official subreddit and a couple sites where you can match up with people of similar skill, location, languages and mind sets.  In short, if you're not a competitive person or not a serious first person shooter fan then I'd give this a miss or pick it up when it's on sale. If you play FPS games a lot and are competitive then this game is defiantly worth it.

Rainbow Six Siege is solid. I love it, so first I will talk about the things that aren't that great about it.  1 - My mic doesn't work even though it works in every other program and game I have used. When I use the push to talk button people can't even see that I am talking. In a game where team play actually matters this is really important and kind of frustrating. I'm not the only one who has this happen.  2 - No matter how much armor you have, one shot to the head will kill you with any weapon. Some of these guys are wearing helmets that should stop at least a single bullet. In a game where having more armor reduces your speed, armor is worthless. Sometimes someone will pop around a corner and kill you instantly. Which brings me to the next point...  3 - Some of the operators in this game have big, bulky helmets and earmuffs (GSG9 especially) or gas masks (SAS). These all count as part of the head. So if someone shoots you in the earmuff, or your big old helmet, or the filter on your gas mask, it will kill you. Instantly. Some characters carry riotshields, which themselves are bulletproof, but usually the tiniest bit of your helmet sticks over the top. If someone shoots that little itty bit of helmet...  4 - The attackers get Grenades like Flashbangs, normal Grenades, and Smoke. The defender, on the other hand, get Nitro. Nitro has a large explosive radius and you can usually detonate it while it is still in the air, unless you threw it on something within the blast radius. Since you can activate it so quickly you can throw it around corners and kill anyone there before they can even react, even someone behind a riotshield. So instead of placing it in hidden spots and waiting for someone to get in the killzone, it is instead a more powerful grenade.  5 - The game really wants to hold your hand. The little drones that search for players have glowing red lights on them, C4 beeps and has a glowing red light on it. One character has a trap that has not only a drill that appear on the other side of the door/window he places it on but has a GLOWING RED LASER on it, which basically makes the character's special ability useless. The objectives, if they are a 'bomb', make beeping noises which help the attackers find them, there is a Call of Duty style grenade indicator which shows you not only if you are close enough to take damage but also if you are close enough get downed by it...  6 - The damage shown on the guns is not the damage actually done. A shot to the head is an instant kill and shots to the legs/arms do reduced damage, but a shot to the chest does not do the damage stated. What is the point of numbers that represent damage if that is not the damage we actually do?  7 - The hitboxes are really simplified. Shooting someones feet is an easy way to kill them if they are stuck in an animation like placing a detonator on a doorframe covered in a barrier (which they themselves can not see through, there is a little gap under the door which can only be seen if you are looking at it from a distance). So basically my complaint is feet do the same damage as the thigh, stomach does same damage as the chest.  And then there are things that will be patched out, like how defenders can glitch through walls during the pregame phase and kill the attackers as soon as they spawn. I've only had this happen once so it is not really a problem. I killed the person that did this (he was on my team) and got kicked by my team (they were probably in a four person squad) but when I rejoined I could not be kicked again (They then accused me of hacking, ironically). I had an AFK guy on my team once and despite having four votes (the teams have five people each) we couldn't kick him. Fun.  Now that we are finally done with all the bad things, why do people love it?  The community is overall great. In my 71 hours of playing I have only encounter one group of people exploiting (the above example) and most people use their mics. If you are the last person on your team and fail miserably people usually are cool about it, and if someone gets angry everyone else will back you up. Usually jerks travel in groups, so you won't see them much playing solo.  There were a lot of bugs with hit registration, and Ubisoft just released an update doubling the tick rate from 30 to 60. !ALL DLC WILL BE FREE! (and I do not suggest you buy the season pass, you do not need to), you will be able to buy operators added post launch with in game credits.  The game has this 'One more round' appeal. Every game you play just makes you want to play a little more, and a little more... and so on.  The game is tactical. If you just run around looking for people without a plan someone will drop you like nobodies business. If you like Search and Destroy in Call of Duty, you would love this game. A lot of people that like CounterStrike also like this game.  If you die you are not just a spectator, you go into support mode. In support mode you can view cameras and spot enemies (which identifies them, showing exactly who they are playing as, and shows your allies their exact location with a visual indication). There is no minimap, you can see exactly where your teamates are through walls. You have the feeling like you are really a team. Working together matters. If you all go through the same door you will get destroyed.  Each operator is unique, to an extent. Twitch gets a drone that can go around and zap people with a low damage taser, Thermite can breach through reinforced walls, Mute can put down jammers that make enemy remote detonators not work in a small radius (like Thermite's Thermite), Thatcher has EMP grenades which counter electronics (like Mute's jammers), Montagne has a riotshield that can cover his entire body while standing up (which allows others to use him as moble cover), Blitz has a riotshield with the capabilities of a flashbang, Smoke has a throwable gas grenade that can cutoff chokepoints for a short time (and a shield will not protect you from a gas grenade), Glaz has a sniper rifle capable of shooting through the windows on the airplane map or through deployable barriers enemies place, Pulse can see enemies behind walls, Rook can give his whole team an armor buff, Doc can revive players with a dart gun instantly and from a distance at increased health, Castle can place down bulletproof barriers that can't be shot through, and using mute with Castle's barriers means that you either have to slowly beat them down, or use Sledge who can break down walls in one hit with his sledge hammer, or use Ash who has a grenade launcher than destroys walls from a distance.  That was a lot of text, and it is not even all the operators, although some of them are just not that useful (like Tachanka, who can place a heavy machinegun which... can't shoot through riot shields, and leave the operator totally defenseless, and does not even have a 360 degree turn radius...) but the point is you can play as a character that completely changes the game. Some characters work together better than others (like the mute/castle example above) and some character play off characters on the other team (like Mute/Thermite counter or Thatcher/mute counter). Fuze can place a device that launches five grenades into a room, but Jager can place down 'ADS' that kill grenades before they explode.  The idea is the game is really deep. It matters more than just what gun you have or how fast you react to situations, but who you play and how you play them. It is very rare to have two games be the same because of how many variables there are. The ability not just shoot through walls but destroy them, placing barricades in windows and doorframes, reinforcing walls (which only Thermite can break through), placing barb wire to slow enemies, placing deployable walls, I've hit the word limit, but I have only begun to describe how great this game is, and it should only get better.

I do recommend this game, however the big deal breakers for me are pretty bad for this game (listed at the bottom).    Pros  + Coop Terrorist Hunt + Coop difficulty levels; normal, hard, realistic + Team Deathmatch; casual, ranked + Easy UI  +  Matchmaking takes up to 5 seconds before finding a game  + NPCs will literally climb out of the building and try to flank you + Headset is important for detecting sounds in specific directions (beepings from bombs, footsteps from enemies, suicide bomber breathing, enemies setting up fortifications while you're still breaching) + Multiple game modes, capture area, hostage rescue, bomb defusal + Short rounds + Destructible environments, you can destroy positions and open up other strategic points of view + Constructiontible environments, you can fortify positions and use it to your strategic placement of other things + Lonewolf scenario missions for the socially awkward + Ping is between 50 and  125  250 + In game voice chat is effective  + Character classes all have abilities which counter each other and works well with other abilities + Hats and character skins + Iconic characters, easy identification  + Free expansions, season pass users get them earlier + You can switch your equipped items and attachments during match setup  + Ranked games punishes leavers + New Players will join your existing game to replace leavers   Cons  -  Hard to cooperate with people who don't speak the same language (English, Spanish, French, Russian so far)  - Not as deep as the first R6 games; weak customization, weak weapon selections, weak item selections - No map plan or blueprint prior to engagement -  Ping up to 300-400 most of the time depending on the host  - Requires Uplay login to play game and to add friends - If Terrorist Hunt Host disconnects, you disconnect from game entirely - Random times drone will fall off the level or clip into walls - They send you into a building with no particular backup on the outside, tons of cop cars, ambulances, and no cover allowing terrorists to roam freely on the open. Some time appearing as though they spawn outside of the siege areas.  - No thermal goggles or night vission goggles - Season pass means for more unlockable goods, there used to be a ton more content for what you got in the game - No custom levels, no custom playable maps

The weapons seem adequately powerful and there are unique operators (character classes) with fun and occasionally useful abilities. The game's classes, or Operators, all feel really good, especially after recent balancing. I don't feel crippled when we take a certain kind, and a good team can easily beat out its bad composition. Balance patches have been well-done and well-implemented.  My biggest complaints are the latency, cheating, and the lighting. Even with my pretty damned good connection, I typically can't find a game with ping under 100ms. This really makes 'peaker's advantage' the meta, which limits a lot of potentially useful tactics. Cheating is rampant in Ranked mode, but rare in Casual, and it's supposedly even a huge problem in the game's competitive scene. Using the recommended brightness settings puts you at a massive disadvantage as it makes any enemy in a shadow practically invisible, and turning up the brightness to see makes everything blinding and ugly.  Overall, these don't detract too much from the experience. The game is actively fun to play, especially with a coordinated team.

This is not the supposed Counter-Strike clone. It is indeed, it's own unique, brilliant game. Do you like games where you actually have to think? Do you like games which are realistic but not overly so that it makes it unenjoyable? Do you like unique characters that have their own style of play and personality? Then Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege is for you.   Every match is a five versus five with three to four rounds (four to five if in ranked). You can pick from up to eleven defenders and eleven attackers. Every round starts off with preperation. Defenders reinforce their location and attackers scout the map with drones.   Gameplay is fluid and intense. It's intense because in this game, any shot to the head can kill you, so being aware of your surroundings is key. The gunplay in this game is magical but the hit registration still needs work (Still very accurate but needs tweaks). In this game, you can destroy any wall, which allows you to be creative with the way you reach your objective.   The graphics are nice. They're pleasant to look at and matches the style of the game. They paid a lot of attention to destructable objects like walls and props because when they are destroyed, it's very realistic. Some textures need a little work but I haven't paid graphics much mind in this game.   All in all. I believe that this game is amazing and will provide me with a lot more hours of fun. I really recommend this game for anyone of those people who like the sound of a tactical shooter with lots of personality.

I decided to do my review after 200+ hours, so there it goes: First, and most important, this is NOT a pay-to-win game, in fact I advice buying the standart edition because everything can be unlocked in-game after some hours playing and since all DLC are for free, the Season Pass only offers you a faster way to unlock the operators. Now, the first months of this game was rough, that is when most of the negative reviews came, mostly because of netcode issues and for a game that is headshot-based this was a big problem. But Ubisoft was always ready to fix any problem reported by the community. There was some hackers in-game, specially in the ranked matches, but after the addition of BattlEye they (the hackers) got all removed and banned. The gameplay is solid and heavily team oriented, but you DO NOT need to play it with friends to have a great time. The community is highly friendly (of course there are some exceptions) and offers great help for newcomers, and some will even end-up being friends with you after some matches. In summary, this is a great game for FPS fans and if you want to buy this game go for it and you won't be disappointed.

The Rainbow Six series continues to release amazing games, and Siege is no exception. Siege's base gameplay is strategic mixed with the twitch shooters that we all know and love. Siege rewards player for playing strategically with operator's unique abilities. Different operators change the way that your attack plan or defense plan will be played out. None of the operators in the game feel incredibly unfair and they all interact with the game in a fun and compelling way. In addition to Siege's Unique multiplayer mode, it comes with a PVE mode called terrorist hunt. Terrorist hunt is a fun way for new players to learn maps and get familiar with Siege's satisfying gunplay. But of course the main dish of Siege is the multiplayer, which can provide many hours of compelling gameplay. Siege is well worth the money, especially if you already like games like CSGO, COD, or BF. And The operator's unique abilities will be a comfortable way to ease into the twitch shooter side of Rainbow Six Siege if you're already familiar with a game like Overwatch or Team Fortress 2.

I'm recommending this game, but it can be very frustrating.   The destructible environments provide for a really fun and cool game experience you can't get anywhere else. The first time you get in a firefight where you are blasting holes in a wall with a shotgun to try and hit the guy behind it, you will understand how fun this can be.  The caveat is that the syncing and netcode are beyond garbage. You will die A LOT to people that you cannot see because they have 'peekers' advantage - meaning if you peek around a corner you can see and shoot the enemies before you show up on their machine. I was on the fence because of the reviews I was reading about this game. What made me buy it was the Steam user reviews.  I only played a couple of the tutorials because I found them boring but they get you your initial points that allow you to unlock characters. If you don't unlock a character before diving into multiplayer you'll be stuck playing as a recruit. The tutorials give a ton of points so I'd say get 1000 points and unlock an attacker and defender, then head into the matches (unless you enjoy the tutorials, there are 8 I believe).  First 5 games, I played with a friend. He was trying to lay prone and kept break dancing on the floor then got shot in the face. Then the next match, we were trying to figure out how to Rapel down a wall and fell to our deaths. We were laughing at how awful we were at the game but after those first 5 matches (which go by really quickly) we started getting the hang of things, learning the maps and combat, getting used to our unlocked characters abilities and how best use them. Needless to say, I sat here for hours playing after being on the fence because I didn't have a full group to play it with.  I don't usually review games on here but this game feels new. Such a breath of fresh air. Combat, tactics, close quarters... This game is seriously a winner on many levels. I've joined groups solo or with one or two other friends. I've never had a full group and I want to be clear that you don't have to have a bunch of friends playing to enjoy this game. Yes you can play ranked and if you do it would probably be a good idea to find some serious people to play with but I played on casual for hours without feeling like I was missing out on anything.   Get a mic, make sure you get your push to talk working properly, and dive in. If you enjoy counter-strike (or used to enjoy counter-strike) you will enjoy this game. It has those great CS moments of 1v1 where you're trying to break the tie and everything is riding on you or the other guy to win it all. (games I played were often tied at 2/2 and ended with a tie breaker round. The map rotates and changes who you play against when someone wins 3 I believe).  Don't let those 7-8 reviews scare you away from this one. It is worth diving into. Aboslutely, 100% worth it.

I want to start with the absolute best element of this game - it's gameplay. When two balanced teams with decent latency duke it out, this game is really on another level. Every game has the potential to be truly different and thus it can really hold your attention, and on top of that, it is far more exciting and immersive than any multiplayer FPS you've played before. I'm going to recommend this, I just want to point out why people are seeing a mostly positive and not an overwhelmingly positive average so that hopefully they can make a more informed decision. I held off on this game for a long time because the reviews weren't totally glowing, and I regret that. The truth is it does have some problems. I'm seeing now how difficult it must be to test this game for bugs, and it has taken a long time for them to work away at it. Some of it is gone now, but beware, it's not all gone. On top of this, I have never come across a game which spends more time loading than this. I understand mostly why it must be that way, but it really cuts away from the fun you could be having. The matchmaking is pretty slow on top of that, so you're really just going to do a lot of waiting for not much playing. My final complaint is that the player base can be extremely toxic. I've never seen so many people just straight up throwing insults around and being rude when there's no need at all. People use chat more to be toxic than they do to communicate about the game, and suprisingly few people use voice chat when it's pretty essential to the game. I recommend this - just please come with a good attitude towards teamwork, a mic, and be prepared to wait around.

***Review Updated 8/1/16 below original review*** 4/21/16: This is hands down one of the best FPS games to come out in the last 10 years. I have had tons of fun with it and definately recieved my money's worth. Why the negative review you may ask? The game lacks any in engine anti-cheat. Fairfight is a data collection tool that catches players based on statistics. It does almost nothing to deter people from hacking, sure it might eventually catch them, but that is too little too late. I cannot reccomend this game in its current state. Within the past two months my team went from about 1 in 5 suspicious games to 2 in every 3. It is almost impossible to enjoy the game when you hit the platinum/diamond rank. Ubisoft claims they are 'Discussing the cheating issue daily in meetings', but this means absolutely nothing to us (the game is 5 months old now...). I will update this review if Ubisoft makes a valid attempt to stop the cheating, but for now I cannot reccomend this game.  5/14/16: Patch 3.0 is out and some of the new QoL improvements look great. I would like to clarify that changing the code of conduct to ban people quicker will accomplish abosulutely nothing if the anti-cheat is not picking them up to begin with. I have heard more people have been banned since the launch of 3.0, but Fairfight can only do so much and take time to detect each new hack. We still need a first line of defense.  8/1/16: I cannot believe I am saying this, but Ubisoft has added Battleye anti-cheat. After playing many matches with it and seeing first hand people getting banned I am extremely satisfied. Patch 4.0 launches tomorrow and with it many great QoL changes. This recent refocus on the health of the game has sold me on the fact that they really want seige to succeed.

Plese read it all, it's worth your time as it explains everything thoroughly.    Real life siege scenario:  -Snipers surrounding the building/area so that if any defender would go outside they would get their brains splattered all over the pavement. -Tons of swat and cops surrounding the building (that in this case could be used by  heavilly  suppressing without actually hitting ( and causing damage to ) any defenders who would stand in front of a broken barricade on a window aiming to spawnkill the attackers. This heavy suppression could act like Battlefield's suppression mechanic and force that defender away from the window and saving the attackers from tons of frustration).   R6S siege scenario:  -Defenders can run outside and do whatever the flying f@ck they want with the only penalty being that they are visible for the attackers at all times while outside ( they don't even become visible right away, 2 seconds must pass after they've gone outside for them to be detected ). -Defenders can peek the windows mentioned above and spawnkill everyone without any risk. -4 out of 5 defenders roam for 99% of the matches thus making the attacker role very unpleasant since the game becomes 'CoD: Inside a building Warfare' instead of the defenders reinforcing everything and the attackers having to strategically create new vulnerabilities or exploit already present vulnerabilities in order to accomplish their mission.   About the game mechanics:  -No scope sway. It feels like a robot is holding the gun. When moving it feels like a wall is constantly under your gun on which you have deployed a bipod since the gun is extremely steady while moving. -You are able to shoot while mid-air and apart from the fact that it doesn't make any sense it also allows a defender to jump off a window and kill the attackers before even touching the ground. -Recoil is pretty present but once you put a foregrip and a compensator it becomes almost non-existent. This shouldn't be the case. -Bullets don't actually come out of the gun's barrell but instead they come out of the rifleman's eye ( center of the scope ) thus making it feel weird, wrong and allowing headglitching which is a massive problem especially when an attacker is peeking a window while rappeling. Instead of seeing his upper torso and his head, you see only the part of his head where the eyes are. -Drones which are very important and can save an attackers life have big, glowing red lights on them that are visible from a mile away. -When hip-firing bullets do 30-45-60 degree turns once they leave the barrell while shotguns' pellet spread is 'magically' reduced when you aim down sights. I know what you might say, that hip fire is supposed to work like that but guns and physics are not! -You are able to aim down sights and shoot while moving prone which ism't physically possible.   Support from the devs:  Ever since day 1 they have been releasing countless patches and hotfixes that address numerous bugs, glitches and issues in general. Every 2-3 months they release new 'Seasons' which means that they release 2 new operators and 1 new map for free! At the start of Season 3 they even implemented a new client-side Anti-Cheat software which is extremely hard to do after the game has been released. They also listen to the community's feedback and adapt accordingly.   About the free operators new Seasons bring us:  Personally, the only good operators we got, were Season 1's. All the others have done more damage than good by massivelly unbalancing the game and causing a lot of problems ( at least they're free ) : -Blackbeard: Apart from the fact that a shield mounted on your rifle makes no sense since you would get a broken shoulder and a serious concusion when stopping bullets with it, it also doesn't make the game any better since once he peeks a window or manages to put his body in cover and have his head covered by the shield he is a god. -Valkyrie: She was supposed to throw her cameras in rooms that were extremely important but had no cameras placed in them by default. Instead, people throw these cameras out of the building and spawnkill the attackers or constantly look through them until they find the perfect timing to kill the attackers by going outside the building ( which should not be possible ) -Caveira: They added a dedicated roaming operator while one of this game's major issues is roaming. Also, this Brazilian theme feels weird and out of place ( it's a game about special forces ) especially if you take into account that in Tom Clany's books, 'Rainbow' team consists only by operators from NATO countries. -( Will update when the Japanese operators will be released ).   About the free maps new Seasons bring us:  They aren't that good. I'd say that they are mediocre, especially the newest one called 'Favela'. They're free at least.   Unbalanced aspects:  -If someone knifes your shield, for an unknown reason your character will put the shield away leaving you open to knives and bullets. Why would someone do that? You stop bullets with that shield and you don't even flinch but when someone knifes you you send it into orbit? Wtf?... -While approaching as a shield operator people just shoot the exposed hand holding the pistol without you having an option to withdraw that hand behind your shield. As a result you die from a mile away. -Too many C4s. Instead of leading the assault with your shield while having your teammates stand behind you for cover you get blown to sh!t along with any teammates who might use you for cover. Especially now with the implementation of Impact grenades, operators who previously didn't have any explosives now have impact grenades. -The SMG-11 aka MAC 10 when used with an ACOG makes a better sniper rifle than an actuall sniper rifle ( Glaz' primary ). Also, how the f@ck do you equip an ACOG to a pistol barrell-lenght SMG?    About the potential this game had:  If this game would represent what a real-life siege scenario would look like it would have been the best and very unique on the market. Instead the defenders can do whatever they want and the attackers could be renamed 'Defenders who spawned outside of the building' since in this game there is no actual deference between 'Attackers' and '(Pseudo-)Defenders'. I think it would also have been a lot better if it would be simply a CTU vs terrorist theme ( and being able to choose from a big list of weapons that could be used no matter the side you got spawned in ) instead of this 'everyone has a shiny gadget', CTU vs CTU system.    This game is not worthy to have Tom Clany's name on it as he would never write something so far from reality where the world hasn't discovered snipers and where guns defy the laws of physics. Damn, it's not even worthy to have the word 'Siege' on its title!   HOWEVER! Although it doesn't depict what a real life Siege would look like and the netcode is terrible ( headshots don't even register a lot of times ) I say that this game is 'Recommended' because it's tons of fun to play, especially with friends. It has tons and I mean a sh!t ton of frustrating moments but the gameplay is fun.
