Rainbow Six Siege siege is one of the funnest tactical fps s i have ever played. As it sits right now there are 2 main modes 5v5 pvp and pve terrorist hunt, both have a variety missions within them. PVP matches take pace in rounds where teams take turns attacking and defending. On both modes players choose from different operators(different for attackers/defenders) with unique gadgets such as a shield to block bullets or a sledge hammer to break walls. Different operators have different armor and speed values. Defenders at the start of a round can choose the objective location and set up defences. Attackers at the start of the round sout with drones which can be destroyed trying to find the objectives.   The big selling point of this game is the distructible enviroment where most wall and some floors can destroyed/shot through rewarding creative people who understand the mechanics and know the maps. Map variety isnt huge but the ability to destroy the enviroment and objectives being in different locations ensures every match feels unique. At one point or another your going to be accused of hacking because you shot someone through a wall which is the most rewarding feeling in the game. Visually the game looks great and every map is feels different.    In my opinion this game plays most similar to counter strike where team work and map knowledge are key but with less emphasis on mastering weapon spread paterns. Just like CS there are no respawns, timed objective based rounds, friendly fire, and you can not regain health by waiting(There is one operator whos gadget can heal though). Headshots are a 1 shot kill with any weapon which can be frustrating at times but personally dont want to see it removed because they reward accuracy and increase the risk of peaking in some situations. Just like in csgo a dropped teammate puts your team at a significant disadvantage however its still possible to win with enough coordination and skill.   I would not recomend getting the game at its full price of 69.99 can, i suggest waiting for a sale or a price drop to at least 30-40 dollars. Net code isnt perfect in this game but is always getting improved. It is frustrating when you die at the start of the round not everyone has a mic. For me i find i cant turn up teammate mic up enough. There isnt enough weapon attatchment variety the only thing i really ever change is the type of sight and put a grip and flash hider on every gun that has the option. Suppresors and lazer pointers arent worth it in my opinion. Operators are very slow to be buffed or nerfed and not all are worth it (poor tachanka:( ...). There isnt really any single player content terrorist hunt the pve mode can be played solo but you want to do it coop most of the time. At lower elos it can be frustrating with some teams that want to play search and kill instead of playing the objectives.    To put it shortly RS S is a unique tactical shooter that exceptionaly rewards smart gamelpay rather than run and gun how ever has aspects that may frustrate some people who want a very polished game or lone wolf players. Not worth full release price for most people.

After 200 some hours, I feel it's safe to say that Rainbow Six Siege is the best multiplayer shooter I've ever experienced. Ubisoft seems poised to market this game as a rival to Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, and I feel it definitely has that potential.   + Graphics. Game is absolutely gorgeous, especially at Ultra with the high resolution texture pack installed. There's a wealth of options, including support for switching between nonstandard refresh rates, a numbered FOV slider, and more antialiasing combinations than you can count. Shader quality is the heavy hitter setting in Siege, so if you're struggling for performance, don't set it to high. There is also a Temporal Filtering option, which uses a complex patchwork of lower resolution squares that combines data from earlier frames; it sacrifices visual quality to increase the framerate and reduce VRAM usage dramatically. A great option for low-end or laptop gamers, or high-refresh rate players on medium-spec rigs.  + The gameplay is dynamic -- every round is different, and yet it remains tactical and team-oriented. Counter-Strike has become increasingly stale to me the more I play Siege. I always check the same spots, throw the same smokes, and plant the bomb in the same places. I've seen the same round a million times, and the fact that there's up to 30 of them in a game only makes matters worse.  + Pacing. Playing as a defender, you're left to roam quietly near the objective as you can hear the footsteps and gunfire of the attackers slowly close in on you. For a while, nothing happens but information gathering. Then, one of your teammates across the map gets downed. Twenty seconds later, an explosion in that direction, then closer. Half a minute more, and the attackers begin their siege, with explosions and destruction pounding the objective area and gunfire flying past your head. Every round is a slow and intense buildup to a climactic and explosive moment of truth.  + Map variety. There's a upper-middle class house, a biker club, a christmas-themed cafe, a colorful favela, a beached yacht in the arctic, a border facility in the Middle East, a coast guard office, and several others, each meticulously detailed and impressive. Many are based on real-life counterterrorist operations, like a compound in the central US or a cramped commercial flight. And all are fileld with plenty of destructible walls, floors, and ceilings.  + Sound. Holy crap, Ubisoft nailed sound in this one. It might not be quite as aurally impressive as the work DICE is known for, but Ubisoft has some tricks up its sleeves. First off, sound doesn't just travel through walls in all directions like in most games. Instead, it travels based on the shape of the map. If there's an enemy shooting in the room to your left, but the only door into your room is to your front, then you'll hear their sounds coming from your front, but if there's a hole in the wall to your left you'll hear them directly to your left. This isn't nearly as misleading as you might think, the audio wizards at Ubisoft have still managed to make tracking players by sound just as easy as any other game. Because sound travels in a path, following it will always lead you to the enemy. In addition, the ambient sounds are incredible. Light humming of AC units and coolers, grandfather clocks ticking and chiming, distant party music, far-away screams when you first fire your weapon, and training soldiers in the distance on a military base are all there to be heard if you listen closely.  + The destruction is not only gorgeous, it adds so much intrigue and strategy to the maps. Opening new sight lines and pathways isn't a gimmick, it's critical to effective play. While games like Battlefield tout their destructive prowess, its gameplay implications are rather shallow.  + The gunplay is tight, diverse, and satisfying. After 700 hours in CSGO I was getting really tired of AK (and only AK and M4, nothing else is commonly used) taps doing nothing, and even though I had mastered recoil control the whole system felt very outdated and unintuitive. Siege takes the gunplay you'd see in most modern shooters and adapts it to foster skilled play. Headshots are always lethal and your first shot will always hit where you aim, leading to some incredibly satisfying shots.  + Operators give the player a chance to specialize in something meaningful. In CS you have riflers and AWPers. Battlefield does slightly better with its Medic, Engineer, Support, and Recon. But Siege offers a wide cast of operators with some very exciting abilities. Valkyrie can throw cameras wherever she likes, letting her keep tabs on the enemy's advance. Blitz has a flash on his shield, making him extremely deadly in a 1v1 situation. Caveira can interrogate downed enemies to give her entire team the realtime locations of the opposing force.  + Ubi's business model is great. Knowing Ubisoft's past reputation I was very afraid going into Siege. I was expecting new operators and maps to be locked behind a paywall and splintering the community, and skins were all going to be bought with real-world cash. None of this was true, all DLC operators and maps are free (with operators being unlocked with ingame currency, which isn't hard to come by). And more and more skins are becoming purchase-able with ingame currency, to the point where some high ticket items are entirely free as far as real-world funds are concerned.  However, every rose has its thorns.  - Balance. I have to commend Ubisoft for managing to keep such a diverse game as balanced as it is, but there's still some pretty glaring faults. Semiautomatic shotguns are overpowered (although this is being addressed by a patch soon), where pump actions are pea shooters. Some operators (Tachanka, Glaz) are hardly useful, while others are must-picks (Thermite, Rook, Valkyrie).  - Lighting. Looking outside a window is like staring into the bowels of the sun itself in the daytime, while you really have to squint to make out lots of things while peeking into a building. While this feature is intended to prevent defenders from picking off attackers before they even get close and to encourage attackers to enter the building, it's still very overdone. For this reason, night maps are much more enjoyable to play because of their more even lighting.  - Networking. Pings are mediocre at best, but the real problem is the semi-frequent disconnects. I don't get them often, but at least once every three games somebody on either team gets dropped from the game. I'm also matched with South American players on US servers on a surprisingly regular basis, and their absurdly high pings make them hard to fight. Peeker's advantage is king, the delay between when you peek on your screen and when your enemy sees you peek is so large that it is always better to be peeking than it is to be holding an angle.   - Voice comms. Ingame voice chat is pretty shaky. Some players are way too quiet when they're otherwise at a good volume in other games. Voice comms also frequently cut out between different screen, or lag out sometimes. It's not too terrible, but it definitely needs improvement.  - Terrorist Hunt. It could be absolutely incredible, but instead it's just something I play for the ingame currency boost. The AI is inconsistent as all hell; for the most part they're stupid and worse at the game than a small child, but the moment you blow a hole in the wall they turn into deadeye marksmen with the spatial awareness of a god. They also spawn outside with no warning, so if you're the type of player who likes to pick off players from an adjacent building, you're sh*t outta luck.  All in all, Siege is well worth whatever the current purchase price is. If you can get it on sale, great, but if not it'll still be worth your investment if you enjoy tactica and dynamic gameplay, and want to experience the most innovative shooter in recent memory.

NOTE: THE NEGATIVE REVIEW BELOW WAS DURING JANUARY OF 2016. THE PROBLEMS ARE FIXED AND THIS IS A FANTASTIC AND COMMENDABLE GAME.  After playing a proper three hours of matchmaking, I can assure you that the servers are completely and totally unusable. During the beta, I thought that the matchmaking system would be redone, but that turned out to be completely false. They barely polished the servers at all. Even after almost a month of the game being on the market, the game still crashes after attempting to join a match in progress, and sometimes exits out after playing through a match. The gameplay, however, is entirely fantastic. I absolutely love the operator system, but the fact that you can barely even play with other people ruins the entire base of the game; teamwork. I would not reccomend this game for people who want to play against other members until Ubisoft fixes their servers (which is likely to never happen).  EDIT (April 17th, 2016) - After having refunded this game for several months now, I decided to come back during the free weekend which just ended recently. During this time, I was able to find out that the servers are fully functional, and matches are easy to come by. As stated before, the game in itself has no flaws, from communication, to teamwork, to balancing. I have repurchased the game as of now, and would recommend it to anyone who seeks a strategical shooter like CS:GO, or to people that like the fun experiences of Battlefield. This, however, is not a 'CoD-like' shooter in the slightest. If you rush in or are impatient, you will die. I love this game.

I haven't had so much fun with a FPS for a long, long time...  Putting this quick & simple:  If you're looking for a fun tactical FPS game, with a totally destructable environment, then look no further.   You have two options for this game, you can play it Terrorist Hunt (kind of Coop) with friends, solo or matchmaking or decide play it more competetive with either Casual or Ranked, or you can mix them how you want and when you want  Information about this Game:  You have 20 basic operators, each to be unlocked by gaining renown (in-game currency gained by playing the game and completing the objectives) consisted in 4 operators per squad, Spetnaz, GIGN, GSG9, FBI SWAT, SAS,  They're divided in two Teams, Attackers & Defenders. Each round, there is a 'Insertion Phase', where you have 40 seconds to use your drones for scouting (attacking team) or reinforce the sorrounding (defenders team)  Then when the 'Insertion Phase' ends, the match starts and has a countdown of 4 minutes  When that part starts, the attackers will have to go and secure the objective, which can be one of the three following:  Secure Zone: You have to get in the objective and hold it against the defenders, or by clearing them out  Disarming Bomb: You need to disarm the bomb, but you can also win by eliminating all defenders or vice-versa  Extract Hostage: You have to go grab the hostage and escort him safe to the extraction zone, the game also ends if the attackers kill him accidentally or the defenders decide to put him out of his misery  The special about this game, is that it plays like a chess, each operator is unique and has a special ability, in the Attacker team there is one operator called Sledge from the SAS, which has a Breaching hammer that destroys walls and floors quickly (you can get kills with it too if you dare) and there is Pulse, a fast operator in the Defender team from SWAT armed with a Heartbeat sensor that kinda works like a 'Wallhack'. You have Twitch in the Attacker team of GIGN that has a shock drone that can destroy cameras and gadgets and at same time provide intel and hurt the Defender team with it's lazer. On the other side there is Kapkan, the Spetnaz soldier which has lazer traps that sometimes can caught the Attackers unaware and by surprise guarding the rooms where they're implemented  Besides the 20 basic operators, there are a total of 8 Season operators, 2 for each Team, and next year there will be 8 more in 2017.  They are harder to get and need more renown and time to unlock, but they're free and you aren't forced to buy the Season pass to get access to them, you just have to play more so you get enough renown to unlock them  In the first Season Pass, there are 4 'DLC Squads'  JTF2 - Canadian Joint Task Force   Buck - Attacker 2 Armor 2 Speed armed with a Rifle & Shotgun Barrel which he can switch quickly between rifle and shotgun so he can provide 'murder holes' for tactical advantage  Frost - Defender 2 Armor 2 Speed Operator armed with bear traps that can caught the unaware Attacker roamers, she also has a Super 90 Shotgun (maybe one of the best shotguns in the game)  Navy Seals - USA  Blackbeard - Attacker 2 Armor 2 Speed with a selection of good Rifles, his special ability is a rifle shield that can protect him for a few shots (he used to be overpowered, now he was nerfed to oblivion)  Valkyrie - Defender 2 Armor 2 Speed - Has the SPAS 12 as shotgun or MPX as SMG, her ability consists of 3 blackeye cameras, which can be put anywere and provide extra intel in the room where they're inserted  BOPE - Brasillian Special Forces  Capitão - Attacker 1 Armor 3 Speed - You can choose between a good support LMG or the Para 303, his ability is a crossbow that can either shoot a fire bold into an area or provide smoke support to the Attacking Team  Caveira - Defender 1 Armor 3 Speed - Her ability is very situational, but once managed she can turn the tide of the battle. Her ability consists in 'Interrogating' the downed foe in order to extract info about the wherebouts of the opossite team, but in order to use it she has to down one attacker and use the ability. She has a good silenced pistol that helps in that aspect and she can temporary run a bit more silent while her ability is on  Now to the last  Japanese SAT  Hibana - Attacker 1 Armor 3 Speed - She can fire a special pellet which can melt the reinforced walls, providing entry points where it would not be possible in other way then using Thermite from SWAT FBI, armed with Supernova shotgun and a small and high RoF machine pistol  Echo - Defender 1 Armor 3 Speed - Has a flying drone with night vision that can stun the enemy so he can take them out  There will be 4 more DLC squads next year, now getting into Pro's and Con's  The Good:  Good Graphics Fully Destructable Environment Each match is played different Use of rappeling to get inside the buildings. Tactical aprouch of the game, you can use flashbangs to temporarily stun the oponent, create holes in the walls with shotguns to shoot the enemy on the other room, give cover with shields, use c4 to wreck the shields Good amount of operators, each own unique on it's own way Each map has it's own diferent zones for the objectives, giving lot of replayability value to the game There is no 'p2w' in this game, you can get everything there is in the game for just playing it  The Bad:  The netcode of the game is a complete mess Peekers advantage The Matchmaking is also a mess, you can get a team of lvl 20 against lvl +100 or viceversa, the more balanced way you can get for this game is to play in Ranked but there are also some problems there I've heard

For a 'BETA' the game was great, but as a triple A title and a price of $60, I expected a lot of the issues in the beta to be fixed- I was wrong.  - The match making still has issues.  - Players still get stuck in loading screens.  - The menus for pretty much everything are not very well designed or intuitive at all.  - The game has been out for 3 days and the Ubisoft servers have already been down/crashed multiple times rendering the game unplayable since even most of the (very limited) single player requires it to be online - Wall physcis, game physics can be a little... weird sometimes. - Game crashes randomly - TOO MANY PROBLEMS FOR $60  PvP:  -Assuming no one crashes, gets DCed or stuck in a loading screen, they are fun and intense.  Terrorist Hunts: - The AI on 'Hard' is really not that 'hard' at all, but the AI on 'Realistic' is all-knowing and will headshot you through smoke, a wall and a barraicade with one bullet.  - Spawning is horrible. You can clear an entire building only to have to go back and clear it again because the AI will spawn in rooms randomly- sometimes directly infront of you on screen, but most of the time it's directly behind you.  ----UPDATE FOR THE PEOPLE IN MY COMMENTS----  Response for Mad Ninja - As stated at the beginning of my review, I said I was going to keep it short and simple- hints why I did not go into detail about the things you are requesting. If you want an indepth review, go read the curators reviews or some gaming websites review. Mine was just a simple snapshot of what stood out from the game to me.   As for your comment about spawning, I have seen [In game] [With my own eyes] enemy AI spawn directly infront of me inside rooms. I have also been 100% sure a room was clear (Only one way in) and while camping that room, have had enemy spawn directly behind me and kill me.  The aiming of bots in 'Realistic' is astrocious. I have watched multiple death cams of myself and end of round death cams, where the AI 'should' have had no idea where the player was located but was able to get off a headshot instantly. The difficulty 'hard' on terrorist hunt is not that hard at all, while the increase in difficulty to realistic makes it nearly impossible. The AI -HAS- changed since the Beta as it was no where near as difficult to complete on realsitc mode during the Beta.   As for the game physics and wall physics, I am referring mostly to the damage that is done by explosives. In many cases the damage of explosives seems to just completly ignore walls entirely and kill anything regardless of material of the wall or location. I have also on occasion had random things [Walls, barriers, barbed wire, equipment, etc] blow up for seemingly no reason or all. Or I have seen a single grenade blow up WAY too much in one room/multiple areas.  Characters also sometime clip through walls and get stuck in the maps. I can recall two occasions where other players have been downed, and upon revival they were stuck in the floor and unable to move. This broke the game as the player was not allowed to attack the enemy, resulting in having to wait 8 minutes for the round timer to expire.  Clipping through walls is a HORRIBLE problem for a game that allows players to shoot through so many surfaces. If players [Legs and weapon barrels] can be seen through walls, it gives the opponent an unfair advantage as they can just shoot through the wall without the other player having any idea he is there.  As for the matchmaking issues, I must repeatedly click to join both multiplayer and terrorist hunts. My game will 'act' as if it is trying to find a new game, tell me it is joining and then kick me out to the main screen for seemingly no reason. I have also had multiple games get stuck in loading screens, seen multiple other players get dropped from games and had games completly crash for no reason at all.  Plus the way the servers update is way to slow for this type of game. The lagg can be absolutely horrible with people and enemies rubberbanding all over the place.  As for the menus, you are correct, that is a personal preferance- but if new players of the game have to ask older players how to upgrade their characters or how to get into the screen to kick inacctive players, there is a problem. Plus some of the menus require the player to use the arrow keys instead of just using the mouse which just doesn't make senes to me. You are right it is not 'game breaking' but definetly annoying and on top of all the other problems... You get my point.  Response to Bucie-B: How about you read the review before you comment. I clearly listed Pros first. If yet very short, they are there.  I honestly hate having to down vote this game. It is incredible fun when it works. But with all the issues with the game and networking.. I cannot and will not recommend to anyone that they spend $60 on this game. It just simply is not worth it.

I wish Steam would let me rate games with a neutral rating instead of just a thumbs up or thumbs down: Rainbow Six Siege can be a decent and enjoyable game, BUT... it's not a Rainbow Six game (lore and gameplay-wise) and not much of a 'tactical shooter' like we saw from the original installments, and other examples like the SWAT series, etc. From the series that brought you pre-planning, realism, high customizability and weapons that YOU must control for more accuracy, Siege turned it into a 'competitive multiplayer' downgrade, with arcadey character movement -  still smoother and more precise than other games like CoD and Battlefield  - and removed offline experience with friendly AI (which is, frankly, an insult to old fans like me) at full-price.  -  Let's get the pros out of the way.  - Destructible environment is cool and accurate (which is the main thing that makes the game a bit less stale and give it a bit of more personality), rappel system, kamikaze terrorists, non-linear gameplay and operators with different abilities and paramilitary gadgets. Level design is also worth mentioning. Controls are responsive and the game doesn't feel like an unoptimized console port with stutters and lack of anti-cheats. You finally did something right, Ubisoft.  -  Lack of a proper singleplayer mode, my biggest gripe  - No friendly AI (either basic or AI to give orders to) like, you know, all Rainbow Six titles before this one. Forget about Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, Delta and milestones. You are all by yourself clearing entire buildings, and even succeed in that! To enjoy this game and make it more realistic, you're forced to jump into multiplayer, where you gotta pray people play tactically and don't use cheats or troll around. You also hope this game will never die, since the playerbase might move into other games in the future, thus 60 beloved bucks wasted. As you can see, I'm not the MP-type of player. Obviously, every game is so much better when playing with friends, but SP is a different experience AND one that lasts forever.  -  Realistic?  - Character movement is arcadey and guns don't have much recoil (or at least, no effort needed to shoot accurately). Ability to lean left and right very fast while shooting accurately with long bursts, 1 second insta-melee kills, aiming down sight while proning-and-moving, still 100% accurate while aiming and moving, no movement and accuracy limits when injured, ability to stop reloading by sprinting. AI terrorists can also be cheating aimboters sometimes, and other times they incompetently do nothing, and for a tactical/realistic/whatever game it's a problem that is not yet fixed.  -  Pricetag and exclusive content . This is a game I consider the most 'cashgrab'-y from Ubisoft. It's a tiny little game sold at 60 bucks (it's cheaper now, but exclusive content are still a problem) and microtransactions containing overpriced gun skins and boosts. Want to know the biggest problem of them all?   Time-limited content and time-limited season passes!  Holy ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥. I feel sorry for the people who paid full-price for a game, only to realize they can't unlock ALL content, unless they open their wallets at the right time. You might say 'they're only cosmetics, so you shouldn't care', but a big fan of a specific videogame wants to unlock everything and beat it 100%. Doesn't matter if it's something that affects gameplay or something that can only be collected. Devs like Ubisoft, Blizzard, etc. are doing the most cancerous business model for their games.  - Just a personal con:  there's lack of mod support.  - This game could be a lot better and varied with custom maps, definitely.  -  No quick-chat function   (à la CSGO) - for people who don't use mics/don't have time to write in text chat.  -  Hitmarkers, kill indicators/announcer (that can't be disabled) and weapon skins.  - The cancer of today's FPS games. They don't belong in a 'tactical shooter' game.  -  Port-forwarding in 2016?  - To make a party and invite friends you need to either open some ports in your router, enable uPnP, or adding your static IP in the DMZ (unsafe) if you happen to have a 'strict NAT' according to the game.  The review says I've played 1 hr of this game, but I played the alpha, closed beta, open beta and the free weekend. The devs made some survey for us alpha testers to give feedback about the game, but from alpha to final release the game didn't change much. I gave this game 4 chances and I also tried to force myself to like it. It's not a bad game, but just disappointing. I couldn't get into it, I'm sorry. I will update my review if future updates will improve things, and will play again once its price drops. 60 bucks is too much for me.  PS: I've been told so many times (mostly experiencing internet's psychological warfare wannabe) that I should not 'go back to the past' and forget about the old Rainbow Six games and singleplayer games in general. That's funny, because the competitive multiplayer scene came around at the same time as the birth of the Rainbow Six franchise. That's hypocrisy, isn't it? My point is that the original Rainbow Six concept is still original, because it's hardly used, and I wish to see it back with modern videogame technology  (since the original games are, sadly, outdated. If Ubisoft doesn't feel like developing a new old-school Rainbow Six game, at least just give me a remastered of the trilogy with better controls and AI).  Just disappointed by the fact that the series has gradually gone down this route, developing the same core concept that we often see in most other games these days.   TL;DR - With no friendly AI, pre-planning, customization and realistic gameplay, this is literally a downgrade from past games (sold at the same price + season pass and microtransactions). In fact, Siege mostly focuses on competitive PvP - which is sadly becoming a trend these days - and 'good-enough' Terrorist Hunt mode.

Since I am bored, I am going to write a long, full review of this game.  Overall, this game has a fantastic concept that is (or soon will be) trashed by greedy money grabbing tactics and horrible severs.  When you start up the game, you have 3 options.   1. Missions that are pretty much just tutorials to help newbies understand the game mechanics. 2. The cancerous Terrorist Hunt Mode 3. Multiplayer  The tutorial missions are fine as they are in my opinion, although some seem a bit too difficult especially since the majority of people that play those missions are people fairly new to the game.  Anyways, on to the actual gameplay!  MULTIPLAYER  This is basically what 99% of the game is, or at least what is focused on, so you would expect it to be flawless, right?   Haha, yea...  You join the queue to get into a match. The recommended time is 30-50 seconds. That seems pretty amazing, but no..  Everyone get's into the match and gets to pick the operator of their choice. Everything goes smoothly. But every single time.. there is always that one guy that is playing on a potato with bent paper clips sticking out of it trying to pick up the signal from his 1 KB/s internet plan. The game takes 5 minutes just to start. This gets super frustrating considering each round only lasts 2 minutes on average.  PROS:  +The multiplayer has lot's of content, fully destructive maps and intense fire fights. +Killing enemies is difficult and satisfying. +Literally no match is the same.  CONS:  -Uplay  -Potato servers that make everyone lag and sometimes causes players to get disconnected  -Godawful netcode (What's that? You shot that guy in the head 17 times and saw blood go everywhere!? He still has 67 health, even though 1 headshot counts as a death)  -Cheaters everywhere. I shoot a guy 15 times and then it says he has full health.  -Frost's shotgun  -Lag is insane  You'll be eyeing a corner, making the best choke point the world has ever seen. You are so focused that even if someone appears for just 1 microsecond, you'll be able to get them.  BAM, you're dead!  You're extremely confused on what just happened. Did someone get behind you? The killcam comes on and you see that the guy came around the corner and was standing right in the open for 5 seconds, and shot you. The lag caused you to not even see him appear! FANTASTIC! (And no, my internet is fine. Thanks for not asking)  -The level 3 guy that has no idea what he's doing and ends up shooting the hostage point blank with a shotgun because logic.  -Buck is severely underpowered. The skeleton key is weak, and his assualt rifle recoils so much you can barely shoot anything.  -You'll be put in a match against fully cooridinated teams that are basically level 150 that will wreck you every single time.  -When you spawn as the attackers, take 5 steps to the left, and get sniped from a window.  -Defenders that jump out of the building and start shooting at you 15 seconds into the match.  -Lack of customization. Each operator has around 2 guns they can pick from, and 9/10 times one gun is 100x times better than the other so there's really no point in choosing.  -25,000 renown for the latest operators that you can get if you buy the season pass. What does this mean? Are the next operators going to be 50K, 100K? Don't force people to buy your season pass. (Keep in mind that even 25K is a bit high considering you only get like 200 renown a match).   Okay, yea.. playing multiplayer on this game is just going to leave you feeling unsatisfied. Don't get me wrong, there are a lot of epic moments that happen, but it's severely outweighed by the all the previously listen bad things.  Time to review the.. ugh..  TERRORIST HUNT  Choose to play alone or with a team, with 3 different difficulties. The harder the difficulty, the smarter the AI.  PROS:  +It's fun.. I guess.. +Good for warming up before going into multiplayer matches  CONS:  -It sucks  -Suicide bombers In a game where a couple well-placed shots means instant death, these bombers are a pain in the ♥♥♥. You'll be cautiously scoping a hallway, when a bomber appears and starts sprinting towards you. You put an entire magazine of ammo into his chest, but it doesn't do anything. He then goes boom-boom in your face, causing you to lose.  There are so many cons about it that I'm too lazy to list them all.  FINAL VERDICT:  5/10 if you're a casual lonely player like me. Probably an 7 or 8/10 if you got an actual squad to play with.  I'll update this as the new content slides in and more patches get released. I have faith considering they are aware the servers are crap and they are fixing bugs, like the invisible Kapkan laser exploit.

The modes consist of breach and clear, sometimes collect a hostage, others destroy a bomb. The maps are extremely linear and offer a minimal amount of destructive enviroment except set areas, there's not many of them on the base game so varaity is at a minimum. In true Ubisoft fashion, Rainbow Six: Siege over-promises and under-delivers in it's latest 'tactical' shooter, and I use that word loosely. What looked to be a fresh take on a saturated FPS market, Siege captured my interest first with its enticing and slightly cringey E3 trailer. In the demonstration, a laughable stereotype of a 'gamer' voice chats with his teammates about strategies and callouts as he and his friends blast their way into a building to rescue a hostage, with superb visuals and lighting, and most cover being showcased as destructable. The final product though is an embarassment coming from a AAA developer and costing a mere 80 ♥♥♥♥ING dollars CDN, which will also be the last money I spend on an Ubisoft title, and I'll explain why.  To start, the final product looks 'good enough'. The intense visuals and lighting effects shown at E3 were scrapped for rather bland console style graphics, and lighting has no aspect on gameplay whatsoever. The free-form destructable environment was also thrown in the trash for preset 'breach panels' in floors, meaning games will be fairly stale and play out the same after you've experienced most of what the game has to offer. Instead of having custom player setups, the game opted to have special characters called 'operators' who have unique weapons and gear, which sounds good on paper, however the asymmetrical classes are not all completely balanced, and some are just far too good not to have on a round, making team composition basically nonexistant. Remember how in the E3 trailer the team was planning between rounds, and they even had a playbook to scribble on? Yeah that didn't make it either, and even if it did, you won't be planning anything in this game, because despite bearing the prestigious 'Tom Clancy' name, this game is about as tactical as any run of the mill Call of Duty rat maze shooter, minus the killstreaks of course. Teammates aren't going to stick to any plan, even in ranked, because this game is too fast paced and twitchy for it.   There is an awkward preparation phase between each round that allows defenders to reinforce walls and setup their gear, while attackers send in remote camera drones to scout the area. Again, this sounds good on paper, however when you have 5 tiny drones scouting constantly against 5 players that are standing around holding buttons down to set up their gear, 1 drone is 9/10 times is going to get in and find the objectives and ID players, meaning every prep phase is basically the same and boring. Defenders stand around way too much setting up gear, and drones will always find the objective on small maps, especially when a player knows the preordained spawn points.  Hostage mode is a complete waste of time, you'll never drag a hostage through a gauntlet indoors like in E3 when you can just jump out the window and run 10 feet to the rescue point, and I wish I was overstating that case, because most hostage rounds play out exactly like that. Also there was clear time and thought put into the outskirts of maps, but they NEVER get used because defenders are not allowed to leave without getting marked for all to see through walls and having their screens blurred with an annoying orange tint and the text 'YOU HAVE BEEN SPOTTED' flashing on their screen. Forget defending hostage rescue points, this game doesn't want you to play that way, it's absurd and insulting to the genre and Tom Clancy name. Counter Strike offers a far better hostage rescue mode, and it uses an ancient game engine, what's Ubisoft's excuse?  In the end, Siege feels half-♥♥♥♥♥ compared to what was promised at E3, there's plenty of things that need fixed in the game that shouldn't have to be asked for, like automatic team killer kicking, map voting, and other blatant oversights like the hostage mode. Coming from a company that has no shortage of resources, Siege is yet another bland, soulless shooter made by people that probably cared but most likely had corporate dumb ♥♥♥♥s meddling in the development process. If you want a real tactical shooter you're probably better off playing Counter Strike or even Insurgency, this game will dazzle the mainstream gamer and disappoint the true FPS fan.

I absolutely love this game, but can't give it a positive review because of the reasons below. I used to play Counterstrike a lot and switched over to this and Overwatch, so I hope that gives a little background into my opinion. I guess the easiest way to explain my thoughts is a simple Pro-Con list.  Pros -graphics look amazing, and run at a consistant 60 fps on my PC, even at the highest settings. -sounds are really well done. Every gun is satisfying to shoot and reload. You can easily tell where enemies are coming from if you pay attention. -Level design is great. Each one has multiple floors and dozens of entrances to choose from, giving you a variety of options on how you can take the objective. -gameplay is ridiculously fun. Seriously it feels really badass breaching through the ceiling/walls with gunfire all around you as your team pushes in, not to mention strategizing a plan with your team beforehand. -Great community too, 99% of the games I've played I've had a great time talking with my teammates, and even the enemy team. Besides the occasional hacker, everyone is a good sport and they're open to new players and willing to show you the ropes. -Gun customization is fun  Cons -Queue times can range from immediately jumping into a game to waiting more than 10-15 minutes. Sometimes after waiting forever to join I can back out and restart the search and suddenly join a game after 12 seconds. -In game credits called renown: you don't get the operators that you can play as when you get the game. you have to unlock them through saving up renown and buying them in the operators page. Most only cost 500-2000, but the newer operators cost 25,000. Each. and that doesn't include weapon attachments, or skins, or anything. Just the basic equipment and gun(s). Getting all the attachments you want on a gun can go up to 800+, and even more if you want to be able to have a choice between different sights/muzzles/etc when picking at the start of a round. -So you may be wondering how fast can you earn renown in order to get this stuff, well luckily there are some single player situations that grant you 200 renown for each of the 3 objectives you complete in them. there's 10 situations each so you can get 6000 total if you really want to grind that. If you want to play multiplay you also get renown, but it's only 100-300 renown each game, and depends a lot on wether your team wins or loses.  -To expand on the last point, the game feels like a grind at times when you're focused on gaining renown by playing as many games as possible, but since it takes close to half an hour to find, play, and finish a game, you're only getting maybe 800 every hour. Not to mention times where you get randomly disconnected for no reason or even worse, stuck on a perpetual loading screen that won't let you back out unless you alt+f4. -So you want to play one of the new operators that came out? well I hope you're happy with paying either $5 of in-game currency for each one, or paying an additional $30 for the season pass, even though this is a full price game at $50.  TL;DR: They have a really, REALLY, great game here that's hidden under a pile of ♥♥♥♥. It has, by far, the best online multiplayer gamemodes I've ever played but you have to deal with their ♥♥♥♥ servers, and grindy in-game economy, to really appreciate it. Maybe after they've fixed their terrible servers and either made it easier to gain renown or got rid of the system all together, I can consciously say that I'd reccomend this game.

This is an outdated review, many things have changed (for the better and for the worse), I'll update the review to the latest patch eventually.  UPDATE for Patch 1.1:  The patch fixed minor issues. But not enough to compensate the patience invested to handle all the random issues within the game.  Biggest problems still are present in the game, the most important issues are: Netcode issues, random disconnections and random high ping spikes, there are many more, but these are the most annoying ones.   I'll put you an example. If you play with your friends 5v5 for 10 matches (casual or ranked) in a row. I can be so sure that at least 2 of your team or the oponnent team will suffer a random technical issue before the 5th match, eg: random disconnections or error, netcode issues, high ping spikes, etc.   Still feels like a Beta, get it for $30, is not worth $60 for what it offers.  If this was a Beta, it would be a solid Beta. If this was at $30, I would put down the standards a little bit. But, this is a game for $60, you must have good standards for a well known Franchise, for a $60 product, the consumer it is expecting a product that should work at 100%.   I will update the Review for the next Patch.   --------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------   Review for the Original build 1.0  I played the closed Beta and Open Beta, Ubisoft didn't bother to fix many things, and I don't know if they are working on the most of important issues (Netcode as an example).  Can't recommend because: 1.- Is not worth $60 (got it for $38 instead), wait for a good sale. 2.- Netcode issues, and this is the most important issue we all have. Competitive players will be so frustrated. Ubisoft shouldn't be bothering about e-sports when Rainbow Six Siege netcode is not good. It is worse when Battlefield 4 launched. 3.- I'm not surprised why the RS core fans are dissappointed, no Campaign.  4.- Lack of customization. 5.- Compare the RS SIege from E3 build to the current one, you''ll be even more frustrated. 6.- You might have issues with Uplay. 7.- Always Online 8.- There are reports with different kind of Rigs, from mid high to high end Rigs that have issues with the performance, including some SLI configurations. 9.- Only dedicated servers with Ranked matches 10.- There is a glitch where you can see which operator your team has before the match begins. And if you are playing casual, doesn't matter. But competitively, depending in the map AND objective it actually matters a bit. Minor bugs and glitches are consant, but it will get annoying later on, example:  -Drones sometimes just fall in the map. -Sometimes, you can get through the wall when rappelling (instead going up, down, left or right), so anyone can see you from the other side of the wall (and shooting you down). But it gets fixed automatically in a moment. -Joining a squad with your friends sometimes doesn't work properly, or you are in the squad already, but doesn't proceed with the matchmaking, you'll have to reboot the game to fix it. -It is very rare when it happens, but the sound in a match fades out, it can ruin the experience and you can lose a match because of it. In overall, It feels like a Beta.   Some opinions:  The Microtransactions and Skins are meh, doesn't matter how much money they put in. If you have a good team, you'll be fine. Skins are merely cosmetics in the weapons, doesn't improve your gameplay, only few you can get them with in game currency, but most of them only with real currency or money.  I recommend it because: Teamwork it is necessary for victory. Don't forget to configure the Mic for Push to Talk. If you like ''tactical camping'', you might like being the defender.  AI it is decent, but not that good. If you play for casual fun (not competitively), you might like the game. Sound design is good. The sound enviroment plays a huge role.    Ubisoft is working to fix some of these issues with a patch. I will update this Review after testing the new update.

Each character has A special ability, 2-4 types of primary, 1-2 types of pistols. and two pieces of equipment. They are weighted in scales of 1-3 and armored aswell 1-3. I had played the original Rainbow 6, as well as Rainbow 6 Rogue Spear, both when they were brand new games back in the late 90s. The appeal to those games, and indeed the appeal of the entire franchise, was the tactical planning involved in the single player missions. The story that progressed from mission to mission, in both games, kept the player involved, and feeling as if they were unpeeling an onion-like storyline that kept getting deeper and deeper, as the missions got harder and harder.  This legacy is nowhere to be found in Rainbow 6 Siege. There is no tactical planning. There are no friendly AI 'operators' that you can command. No squads, no overview, no story, no plot. This is just another shooter game, made on the back of a once-great franchise, for the purpose of selling DLC by making unlockables that are so difficult to grind, people are more inclined to shell out a few bucks to just buy the in-game currency...  ... but for what? Why would you want to buy anything in-game? It doesn't help you advance through a compelling storyline, where the unlockable items might be required to complete any specific mission. It only helps you to use different (although not often 'better', as each operator is a 'YMMV' type of thing) equipment that's nifty to play with. (e.g.: Riot shields and mounted light machine guns)  Then there's the hacks. My second multiplayer match, I had a guy say 'watch these hax', and he proceeded to just run around and headshot all 5 of the opposing team without aiming.  And througout it all, I have yet to be able to participate in voice chat during multiplayer... a problem that is evidently very widespread, long-standing, and still unresolved.  I bought this game for $15 via Steam. Because of this, unlockable things are far more of a 'grind'. That's fine. I feel like I saved myself the additional $45... because those unlockable things aren't all that compelling or necessary anyway. At least I got to experience the game and know I made the right choice to not waste any MORE of my money on it.

But if you're not, then don't bother. It's not worth the time or money.

There are pros and cons to this review. Compared to Vegas 2 I wouldn't recomend this game if you are a die hard fan of the Rainbow 6 series. However that being said there are a lot of cool new things if you like tatical shooters.   The controls and feel of the game have compleatly changed to a more of a COD handling experience, with quicker movement of your operative and you can no longer lean against walls and blind fire like Vegas 2. But you can lean to look while aiming. The physics have changed and there is much less ragdoll. You can no longer customize your operative like in vegas 2 and there is no main storyline. so some of the leveling incentives are not as motivational and is less immersive. The AI can seem overpowered at times and proves it watching the kill replay camera on single situation missions. However the ammount of stragity has incressed amazingly and there is so much more you can do than Vegas 2. There is a lot of ephisis on teamwork now which is great. The AI has become very smart and you cant just go in shooting . If you are thinking this is going to be the next Vegas 2 and loved that game so much and was waiting for the better awesome verison your wrong and I dont recomend this game. But if you like all FPS games and are a COD (i hate by the way) fan and want a tatical twist on the game then this is your game. Overall Im very disipointed with what they have done with the series and the reason I liked Vegas 2 so much was for the uniqueness of it and the ability to customize your guy and loadout. now things are much more limited and have a more arcade feel than an actual simulation.

It's been some time since my last review of this game, but here are my thoughts after a few more weeks of gameplay; This game is under-patched and over-hacked.   Patches are rare and news updates constantly revolve around new content, with no recognition of the absurd cheating running rampant in the community along with irritatingly horrible netcode and gargantuan hitboxes that they have claimed to fixed, but alas no changes.   The matchmaking system takes upward of 10 minutes to find a game, eventually pooling you with other people on the opposite side of the world and everyone sits and waits for half of the other team to leave before the game actually starts.   Just another game where matchmaking doesn't work and server hosting needs to be in the players hands, allowing devs to fine-tune the game. But here, you're paying money to play a game inevitably against a hacker who will grief you in competitive 'ranked' play and you will die over and over until you join another game with another hacker, only to relive the experience for who knows, up to 30 minutes of griefing? With no power to report or remove the player, you could just leave the game, but then you will be penalized and unable to play ranked for 10 minutes because, 'Shame on you for quitting.'   I can't recommend a game like this when so many others have achieved the same basic qualities of a standard FPS gameplay to a standard that is so much higher than this. I can't believe a company would think it's okay to release a game and not have patched obvious necessities within 2 weeks time of the last patch. I'm pretty sure people don't want to get their nuts stepped on for 2-4+ weeks by griefers while you write a giant service pack for a newly released game engine, but that's exactly what's happening. Similar situation with GTA5 and cheaters, but that game is much more fun.

Back in the day (sortof), I used to play in the beta for RSS. It showed potential to be a great game with plenty of teamwork and gameplay, if lacking in variety. So, well, I guess here's my review of Rainbow Six Siege by Ubisoft. (30/7/16 Australian Date)  *Sees Rainbow Six Siege is free to play during the weekend *Downloads and installs RSS *Goes to start game, and what do you know, Uplay is still a thing *Starts up game, watching the pretty cutscenes that noone actually watches *Whew, finally finished cutscenes, now to play the game *Two words that I dreaded to see appeared on my screen *Creating squad *Always creating squad, no matter how many times I reinstall  Now, enough of that, and on to the serious part. At the time of writing this review, this game has been out for more than 7 months, almost an entire year, and yet as soon as I install and start trying to play the game, it breaks on an infinite loading screen. Now, I know what you might be thinking, 'But reviewer, why don't you just try to mess around with your router settings to get it to work', and while that might generally be what you have to do, it isn't something you SHOULD have to do just to play a game that has been out for 7 MONTHS.   I'm sad to say this game has most definitely failed to live up to its potential, squandering it on who knows what. Rather than fixing gamebreaking bugs that have been in the game since release, Ubisoft has instead opted to release yet more content, making the game even more broken than before. I can safely say that this game is NOT RECOMMENDED!

The game had some very promising content and gameplay. But that’s where it stops UBI is infamous and notorious for having great vision but suffers from myopic creativity and this title is some of the greatest evidence yet. In golf and Baseball, they say it’s not just about the swing, it has a lot to do with the follow through. *Hint Hint* UBI that goes for game developing as well. After months of frustration my limit has been reached. Snails show more concerted effort to get things done than UBI. Sloths, chained to Rosie O'Donnell, swimming in an Olympic sized pool full of molasses shows more earnest and vigor to get things moving than UBI. The game had so much potential to turn the FPS market upside-down than many games in the past 5 years. What they did however is release a broken game. Then proceeded to release fixes as and when they felt like it. Game breaking bugs and glitches reigned supreme. Then came the hackers. Then the 8-year-old team killers. All these things coupled with UBI's lack of enthusiasm in releasing a decent amount of content has driven game play to an all time, record setting, level of repetitiveness.  With only two modes of online gameplay and very few maps you are left feeling a little on the jilted side. So they pour out weapon skins, boosters and little trinkets to hang on your weapon yet the major issues that players actually want fixed are left. A game of this proportion should have way more content than what has been released to date and the gameplay bugs that have continued to plague the game and its community should be fixed within a few days of discovery not left to cause gameplay to suffer so bad as to make those dedicated players want to give up. Yes, there will always be hackers and players whom will take advantage of in game bugs but again that’s why UBI should be more on its toes than they are. Don’t wait 3 months to fix a game breaking glitch such as the dreaded Castle Reinforcement glitch that hung around for months or the pregame setup slaughter glitch that cause many of the honest players leaving the game. Modes like Pilot Escort and Team Survival, being staples of the original Rainbow series have been discarded like a cheap hooker on the curbs of Los Santos. Other ambient issues that the game lacks miserably of are things such as effectible lighting (Shooting the lights out), weather effects, reflective team damage (for those that enjoy Team Killing), hostable lobbies so as not to have to wait up to ten minutes to get into a match.  There’s more but I’m tired of typing….It’s broken, they don’t care, don’t buy it. I warned ya.

Here's what is now standard business practice for games publishers like ubisoft and EA and all the other craptastic games publishers.  Step 1: Hype up their 'game' with lots of highly scripted and suspicious looking 'gameplay' trailers  Step 2: Hire big name actors or well known public figures to talk about the game who have no ♥♥♥♥ing clue about the product to read it from a script or outright make up utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t about it that makes no sense to the actual game, for some reason this particularly irks me because it seems like they haven't even tried playing the game properly for five minutes  Step 3: Give pre-orders and a release date en masse to generate even more hype, offer up exclusive usually game breaking content for people who pre-order the game or alternatively, offer up something that has no ♥♥♥♥ing worth whatsoever ( Usually some sort of skin for a gun or outfit for a character ) and tack on £10 or so to the original base price  Step 4: Release the game, people play it only to discover that there is far less content than what was promised, outrage will soon follow so either go quiet and never respond to any emails hoping the outraged gamers will go away. Or issue a grovelling apology and talk about how they made mistakes and will try to fix it all.  Step 5: Ignore the gamers in either previous scenarios  Step 6: Start releasing DLC content that was prepared before games release and what the developers really worked on, usually the DLC can be most charitably described as what I call 'content unlockers' as the data is already there and they have the models prepared but they want to charge the price of a full independent game for you to unlock it. ill make this review simple and to the point.  the game itself ( how it plays, looks, feels etc.)  is fantastic, looks great, the feel of the combat when shooting, feels rewarding and not sensory numbling. the simple objective based missions make for some quick fun games. its so much fun jamming with friends and clearing the the buildings and rooms. this game would have alot of replay value if it wasnt for its problems that ill get in to.  now the problems, the reason i will rarely pick up this game now on.  1) having to use ubisoft launcher on top of steam launcher is stupid. this setup causes more problems then it does provided features for gamers. its a pain.  2) the match making system is terrible, having to wait 2-5 mins to play a simple terrorist hunt (co-vs-AI) is not acceptable(if you cant find 5 people looking for a co-op game then off load the team with bots, dont make us wait). im fine with waiting that long when i want to play a normal online mode, however, if i just want to jump on and play realy quick your only option are situations, which sucks because you cant modify character or thier load out.  3) the party system is broken, through a 3-4 hour session of playing this game, playing with a few diffrent friends we all had to restart the game, ubisoft launcher and steam over 10 times each. you have to use the ubisoft launch in order to invite friends, its not user friendly, and either doesnt invite the person or you get a error when connecting to group ( and yes we adjusted the settings to open up group invites)  in short, the game is awesome, really fun to play, even more with friends, however, All of the features that help you load the game, interact with friends, and get in to the game to play, are down right awful for a fully released game. its these problems that are keeping this from being not just a big hit but more cruically, a enjoyable game for gamers.
